speaker: The Speaker
theText: Order! It being 9.30 children.The following answers to questions were circulated: Taxation: Bankruptcy Laws (Question No. 1458) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 February 2003: (1) Has the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) at any time over the last seven years retained any barrister who has used bankruptcy as a means of avoiding taxation obligations; if so, (a) which barrister or barristers, (b) on how many occasions was each barrister retained and (c) what was the most recent date that each barrister was retained. (2) Has the ATO at any time over the last seven years retained any barrister while that person was bankrupt; if so, (a) which barrister or barristers, (b) on how many occasions was each barrister retained and (c) what was the most recent date each barrister was retained. (3) Was question No. 2455 asked by the Member for Barton on 26 March 2001 unanswered by the time of the dissolution of the 39th Parliament in October 2001; if so, why. (1)-(2) In the majority of cases, the ATO retains its barristers through the office of the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS). In such instances, the ATO is reliant on the checking processes utilised by AGS. AGS engages counsel consistently with the requirements set out in the Legal Services Directions issued by the Attorney General’s Department pursuant to section 55ZF of the Judiciary Act 1903. Wherever possible, AGS relies on existing knowledge of a barrister’s reputation and, in particular, that the barrister has not used bankruptcy as a means of avoiding taxation obligations. Similarly, in those instances where the ATO directly briefs counsel, the ATO relies on prior knowledge of the barrister’s reputation that they have not used bankruptcy as a means of avoiding taxation obligations. (3) Please refer to Hansard. Taxation: Legal Profession Project (Question No. 1548) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 2003: (1) Why does the 2001-2002 annual report on the activities of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) omit a chapter titled “Legal Profession Project” (LPP) which appeared in the 2000-2001 annual report. (2) Where can the report of the activities of the LPP be found for the period 2001-2002. (3) Does the LPP still exist; if so, what is the nature of its work and to whom does it report. (1) to (3) Refer to Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report 2002-03. Taxation: Outstanding Tax Debt (Question No. 1549) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 2003:
title: Notices 1 Condemns Without Reservation The Recent

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Further to the information provided at page 63 by the Commissioner of Taxation in the annual report of 2000-2001 that 590 barristers had income tax debts of about $52 million, what is the current sum of the outstanding tax debt to be collected from barristers in NSW. (2) Does the drop in the number of barristers with outstanding debts from 590 to 432 from 1999-2000 to the 2000-2001 demonstrate the success of the Legal Profession Project (LPP); if so, how; if not, why not. (3) Is the success in the project supported by the statistics cited by the Commissioner of Taxation on page 63 of the 2000-2001 annual report that overall the number of cases for barristers decreased 26 per cent, and the total debt dropped 14 per cent; if so, how; if not, why not. (4) Did he see that segment of the annual report at page 64 titled “Be more involved with trustees” in which the cases of Re: Davison– Special Case to the Full Court of the Federal Court and subsequently reported as In the matter of Davison, Donnellyv Davison [2000] FCA 1396 (6 October 2000) are cited; if so, how has the Commissioner of Taxation more vigorously pursued debt recovery involving barristers using trusts to avoid tax. (5) Has he been made aware of the five judgments in the Federal Court of Australia of (a) Prenticev Cummins [2002] FCA 1140 (13 September 2002), (b) Prenticev Cummins [2002] FCA 1165 (19 September 2002), (c) Prenticev Cummins [2002] FCA 1172 (19 September 2002), (d) Prenticev Cummins (No. 4) [2002] FCA 1215 (2 October 2002) and (e) Prenticev Cummins (No. 5) [2002] FCA 1503 (5 December 2002); if not, why not. (6) In the matter of Prenticev Cummins No.5 (Fed Ct Ref N7481 of 2002) is he aware that the reported judgment notes that Mr Cummins became bankrupt by his own petition in December 2000 and that between 1995 and early 2000, Mr Cummins failed to lodge any income tax returns and owed an estimated $955,672.92 in unpaid taxes to the Commissioner of Taxation. (7) Is he aware that the said report in N7481 notes that the trustees of the bankrupt estate of Mr Cummins seek to recover certain property or funds said to have been transferred by Mr Cummins to his wife and to the trustee of the Cummins Family Trust. (8) Is he aware that, in like fashion, there was also an intent to transfer property out of the reach of creditors in the pending proceedings before a full examination by the Federal Court of Australia on 19-20 February 2003 in the matter of Mr Stephen Archer, a former barrister now the subject of his third serial bankruptcy. (9) In light of the similarity of facts between the Cummins and Archer matters with intent to transfer property out of reach of creditors, can he say whether the Commissioner of Taxation is prosecuting with full force, his powers under section 121 of the Bankruptcy Act and elsewhere, with respect to those 590 barristers deliberately transferring property or other assets so as to defeat creditors, principally, the Commissioner of Taxation; if so, how; if not, why not. (10) What is the number and percentage of those 590 barristers who are engaged in activities to defeat creditors involving (a) the transfer of their personal assets into family trusts, (b) the transfer of their personal assets to their spouses and (c) other transfers, gifts etc. whilst still having significant outstanding debts to creditors, principally the Commissioner of Taxation. (11) Is he able to say how widespread is the practice of what may be described as asset stripping amongst barristers in NSW and in the other membership lists of the Bar Associations of all the States and Territories; if so, how; if not, why not. (1) to (4) Refer to the Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report for 2002-03. (5) to (8) The matters referred to are on the public record.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(9) to (11) In the majority of cases the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is able to enter into payment arrangements which enable full payment of outstanding amounts of tax. The ATO has fully pursued those cases where it appears that bankruptcy is being used as a ploy to avoid paying tax, for example, cases where the ATO is the sole creditor. In a few of those cases it would appear that assets have been transferred under family law arrangement to put assets out of reach of creditors. In the recent case of Prenticev Cummins (No 6)[2003] FCA 1002 the trustee has been successful in recovering assets transferred to the wife to pay outstanding tax debts. Taxation: Lodgment of Returns (Question No. 1550) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 2003: (1) Further to the Commissioner of Taxation’s annual report of 2000-2001 in which it is reported that the Commissioner has demanded that 771 barristers lodge tax returns, (a) how many returns have been lodged by those 771 barristers and (b) how many returns are outstanding. (2) What are the details of the “outstanding years” of those 771 barristers who have one or more years of outstanding tax returns. (3) With respect to the Commissioner of Taxation’s report that only 56 per cent of the NSW Bar Association were current with their tax returns, what are the current numerical and percentile breakups of both data and statistics in number of years for outstanding non-lodgments of tax returns by barristers in NSW. (4) What action is being taken to arrest the high percentile of barristers who have one or more years of outstanding income tax returns. (5) What does the Commissioner of Taxation define as a serial offender of non-compliance with taxation law, in particular, non-lodgement of tax returns. (6) Is a serial offender a barrister with a history of (a) two or more consecutive years of non-lodgement or (b) two or more years of non-lodgement, whether consecutive or not, or is there some other definition; if so, what is that definition. (7) What is the total number of barristers registered throughout all Bar Association Registries in each of the States and Territory Bar Associations, who have described themselves by this occupation when filing and for the purposes of lodging their tax returns. (8) Can he confirm the existence of certain barristers who declare themselves to be within either (a) Australian Taxation Office Business Industry Codes (BIC) or (b) other occupations other than as barrister as defined under the BIC or as a barrister yet lodging under another BIC, yet still be practising effectively as a barrister for fee for service; if so, what is the number and percentile of those barristers practising yet not declaring themselves to be barristers for taxation purposes. (1) to (8) Refer to Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report 2002-03. Taxation: Lodgment of Returns (Question No. 1572) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 March 2003: (1) Is he aware of reports that Mr Clarrie Stevens, QC, did not lodge an income tax return for twenty years whilst practising as a barrister between 1976 and 1996; if not, why not. (2) Is it the case that Mr Stevens has acted for the Taxation Commissioner; if so, on how many occasions has he been retained by the Taxation Commissioner and for what periods of time.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) What checks does the Taxation Commissioner undertake before retaining the services of a member of the legal profession. (4) Is he able to say whether the Taxation Commissioner considered the question of whether Mr Stevens is of good fame and character before retaining his services; if so, what were those considerations and when was this question considered, if not, why not. (5) Is there a procedure whereby the Commissioner of Taxation determines the good fame and character of a legal practitioner retained for the purposes of assisting/representing him in litigation, policy advice, and/or legal work; if so, what is that procedure, if not, why not. (6) Are there criteria by which the Taxation Commissioner appoints, retains, employs or otherwise engages legal practitioners on a fee-for-service basis; if not, why not. (1) Yes. (2) Mr Stevens was engaged by the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) to provide legal services to the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) on several occasions during the early 1990s. (3) In the majority of cases, the ATO retains its barristers through the office of the AGS. In such instances, the ATO is reliant on the checking processes utilised by AGS. AGS engages counsel consistently with the requirements set out in the Legal Services Directions issued by the Attorney General’s Department pursuant to section 55ZF of the Judiciary Act 1903. Similarly, in those instances where the ATO directly briefs counsel, the ATO relies on prior knowledge of the barrister’s reputation that they have not used bankruptcy as a means of avoiding taxation obligations. (4) to (6) See answer in question 3. Taxation: Tax File Numbers (Question No. 1588) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 March 2003: How many (a) barristers, and (b) solicitors or lawyers, registered with any Bar Association or Law Society, do not have a tax file number. (a) and (b) Nil. Taxation: Legal Services Occupations (Question No. 1589) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 March 2003: What is the total number of taxpayers recorded by the Australian Tax Office under the industry code No. 78410 it uses to identify taxpayers engaged in the following legal services occupations: advocates, barristers, conveyancing services, legal aid services, notaries and solicitors. As at 1 December 2003, the number of taxpayers with an active Australian Business Number with the Taxation: Taxpayer Debt (Question No. 1590) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 March 2003:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) What was the amount of taxpayer-debt carried by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) immediately before the introduction of the New Taxation System. (2) What is the current amount of taxpayer-debt carried by the ATO. (1) to (2) Details of amounts of debt carried by the Australian Taxation Office as at 1 July 2000 and at 30 June 2003 are available in the Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report 2002-03. Taxation: Tax File Numbers (Question No. 1614) Ms Burke asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 March 2003: (1) How many Tax File Numbers (TFNs) have been issued by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). (2) How many TFNs have been: (a) associated with the lodgement of a tax return in the last 12 months, (b) not associated with the submission of a tax return in the last 12 months and (c) found by the ATO to be inactive or no longer operational. (3) What are the criteria for determining the continuing use or functionality of a TFN. (4) Has the ATO found cases of the issue of multiple TFNs to any individual; if so, (a) is there any legitimate reason for an individual to be issued with multiple TFNs, (b) how many instances of multiple TFN issues have been found, and (c) what is the highest number of TFNs that have been issued to an individual. (5) Does the issue of multiple TFNs provide opportunities to attempt the commission of taxation fraud. (6) Does the ATO undertake any data matching to reduce the instances of multiple issue of TFNs. (7) What steps has the ATO taken to eliminate or reduce instances of multiple TFN issue. (1) As at 17 November 2003, the total number of TFNs issued by the ATO is: Individuals: 20 921 867 Companies: 2 103 566 Partnerships: 1 975 124 Trusts: 1 438 915 Superannuation funds: 614 030 Total: 27 053 502 *Government 23 374 (2) (a) For the 2002 financial year 12,257,743 TFNs (including Individuals 10,465,663) were associated with the lodgement of a tax return. For the 2003 financial year 7,647,171 TFNs (including Individuals 7,212,690) have been associated with the lodgement of a tax return. However the lodgement period has not yet concluded. (b) For the 2002 financial year 13,769,040 TFNs were not associated with the lodgement of a tax return. (c) For the 2002 financial year holders of 7,264,074 TFNs have not been required to lodge a tax return. (3) The TFN has a use that is broader than lodgement of an income tax return. Currently there is no single factor that renders a TFN inactive. A TFN may not be active because the client has died, departed Australia and has no further need to lodge returns, or the TFN is a duplicate record.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Clients who have departed Australia may need to use their TFN to lodge returns in relation to Australian sourced income. Therefore departure from Australia is not a bar to the continued use of the TFN. In the case where clients have an indicator that states that ‘further returns are not necessary’ or ‘not necessary’ for a particular year they may not have a taxable income or it is anticipated that they will not earn sufficient income to be liable for tax. However, these clients may still use their TFN as they may have a future or alternative present need to do so, eg quotation to Centrelink or financial institution. (4) Yes. (a) Generally there are two circumstances where a person may legally be issued with more than one TFN: If a person discovers that their TFN has been compromised, ie has come into the possession of a person not authorised to have that information, then they may apply to the ATO for a new TFN. In those circumstances the two TFNs are linked as duplicates to prevent the client using both for separate purposes. In a situation where a person has been issued with a new identity and that identity is protected, that person may apply for a new TFN to prevent their identity being discovered. In these circumstances the TFNs are not linked for security reasons. (b) A total of 187 104 instances of multiple TFNs issued to individuals have been found and resolved since 1989. (c) The highest number of multiple TFNs suspected to have been issued to an individual is 37. However, this is an allegation only at this stage as the case is currently before the courts. The highest number of TFNs proven to have been issued to an individual is 28. (5) to (7) The ATO checks the identity details of TFN applicants against the existing client register using identity-matching software to determine whether the person already has a TFN. A quality assurance process is conducted on a random sample of actual applications to identify the incidence of duplicate records. Complete checking of all TFNs issued in the preceding seven days is conducted weekly through a data warehouse data matching process. The ATO is currently identifying historical duplicate records through internal matching of the entire client database using a hierarchy of matching criteria. Other ATO initiatives to reduce the instances of multiple TFNs include: the implementation of an auto registration process for Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) clients where identity details are confirmed by ongoing participation in the Australian Crime Commission’s identity fraud register (since February 2002); ongoing actioning of referred identity cases from external (eg Centrelink, Police) and community sources; and ongoing use of the Births, Deaths and Marriages’ Certificate Verification Service (since May 2001), although only NSW and Victorian registries are online. Prospect Electorate: Baby Bonus (Question No. 1681) Mrs Crosio asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) How many people in the electoral division of Prospect received the Baby Bonus in 2002-03. (2) How many people in the electoral division of Prospect received a payment of $2,500 in 2002-03. (3) How many people in the electoral division of Prospect received a payment of $500 in 2002-03. (4) How many people in the electoral division of Prospect have applied for a Baby Bonus payment in 2002-03 and been rejected. (1) to (4) The Australian Taxation Office does not collect information on the basis of electoral boundaries. Where a claimant’s taxable income is $25,000 or less they will be entitled to $500 (although this amount is reduced where the claimant did not have legal responsibility for and care of the child for the whole year). Taxation: New South Wales Bar Association (Question No. 1885) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 May 2003: (1) Can he confirm whether the Commissioner of Taxation replied to the President of the NSW Bar Association’s letter dated 9 February 2001, on 14 February 2001, to the effect that “…the ATO has not disclosed information about individual barristers to Mr Paul Barry”. (2) Has the ATO disclosed any information to Mr Paul Barry of The Sydney Morning Herald; if so, (a) what was that information, and (b) will he make it public; if not, why not. (3) Can he confirm that the letter from the Commissioner says: “As you would be aware, our understanding of our secrecy and privacy obligations under the law is that we cannot provide you details of individual cases for the purpose of considering whether to bring proceedings against a barrister for professional misconduct”. (4) Does the Commissioner recommend that the NSW Bar Association “consider being more specific as to what conduct would, under the Bar Rules, constitute professional misconduct”; if so, how would this clarification affect the Commissioner’s assertion that information about particular barristers is precluded from release under privacy and secrecy laws. (5) If no relationship between clarifying rules of professional conduct under the Bar Rules and privacy and secrecy law exists, then will he call upon the Commissioner of Taxation to explain what his policy on release of information is; if so, when; if not, why not. (1) Yes. The Commissioner has replied but it is inappropriate to comment on the terms of the reply. (2) Yes. In response to requests for information from Mr Barry, the ATO provided general information in aggregate form about compliance issues associated with NSW Barristers. (3) to(4) See (1). (5) Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 prevents the Commissioner of Taxation from discussing the affairs of individual taxpayers with others except when expressly empowered to do so under the Act. The NSW Bar Association is not an entity to which the Commissioner can provide such information. Throsby Electorate: General Practitioners (Question No. 1894) Ms George asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 26 May 2003: (1) What was the number of (a) general practitioners, and (b) specialists in the electoral division of Throsby in (i) 1996, (ii) 2000, and (iii) currently.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) What was the ratio per 1000 of population of (a) general practitioners, and (b) specialists in the electoral division of Throsby in (i) 1996, (ii) 2000, and (iii) currently. (3) What is the number and percentage of (a) general practitioners, and (b) specialists in the electoral division of Throsby that bulk billed in (i) 1996, (ii) 2000, and (iii) currently. (1) (a) & (b) The number of general practitioners and other practitioners in the electoral division of Throsby in (i) 1995-96, (ii) 1999-00, and (iii) 2002-03, is as follows: Medicare: Number of Providers in the Federal Electorate of Throsby Type of Provider 1995-96 1999-00 2002-03 General Practitioners 106 103 104 Other Practitioners 44 47 41 Total 149 150 146 (2) (a) & (b) The ratio per 1,000 of population of general practitioners and other practitioners in the electoral division of Throsby in (i) 1995-96, (ii) 1999-00, and (iii) 2002-03, is as follows: Medicare: Ratio per 1,000 population of Providers in the Federal Electorate of Throsby Type of Provider 1995-96 1999-00 2002-03 General Practitioners 0.890 0.814 0.811 Other Practitioners 0.369 0.375 0.320 Total 1.259 1.189 1.131 (3) (a) & (b) The number and percentage of general practitioners and other practitioners in the electoral division of Throsby who bulk billed in (i) 1995-96, (ii) 1999-00, and (iii) 2002-03, is as follows: Medicare: Number and Percentage of Providers who Bulk Billed in the Federal Electorate of Throsby 1995-96 1999-00 2002-03 Type of Provider No. % No. % No. % General Practitioners 103 97.2 98 95.1 102 98.1 Other Practitioners 39 88.6 40 85.1 37 90.2 Total 141 94.6 138 92.0 140 95.9 Notes to the Tables These statistics relate to all providers of at least one service on a ‘fee-for-service’ basis and for which Medicare benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the years in question. Excluded are details of services to public patients in hospital, to Department of Veterans’ Affairs patients and some compensation cases. In general terms, practitioners with at least 50% of Schedule fee income from non-referred (GP) attendances in the June quarter of the years in question were considered to be general practitioners. All other practitioners, including optometrists and some dentists, who provided services under Medicare, were categorised as ‘other practitioners’. These statistics were compiled from Medicare data by servicing provider postcode. In compiling statistics for the electoral division of Throsby, since some postcodes overlap Federal electoral division boundaries, statistics by servicing provider postcode were mapped to electorate using data from the Census of Population and Housing showing the proportion of the population of each postcode in each Federal electoral division. Taxation: New South Wales Bar Association (Question No. 1896) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 May 2003:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Is he aware of a letter sent by the NSW Bar Association to the Commissioner of Taxation dated 16 December 2002 titled ‘Tax-delinquent Barristers and Statutory Secrecy’ (Reference 01/120). (2) Did paragraph 21 of that letter ask the questions: (a) “how was it possible for such delinquency to continue so long”, and (b) “does our system impose excessive requirements of secrecy in relation to taxation affairs”. (3) Has the Taxation Commissioner responded to these questions; if so, what was his response; if not, why not, and when will he respond. (4) What action is he taking to address the serious policy failure identified by the two questions posed by the NSW Bar Association to the Taxation Commissioner. (1) to (3) The Commissioner has responded to the letter but it is inappropriate to go into the terms of the response. (4) Refer to Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report 2002-03. Taxation: Bankruptcy Laws (Question No. 1948) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 May 2003: (1) Further to his reply to question No. 1417 (Hansard, 26 May 2003, page 14643) what is the total number of investigations being undertaken by the Australian Taxation Office in relation to the taxation affairs of barristers and solicitors. (2) What percentage of these investigations relate to the employment of (a) family law and/or bankruptcy, and (b) failure to lodge tax returns. (1) to (2) (a) As at December 2003, the ATO is currently pursuing nine cases involving the apparent use of serial bankruptcy by barristers and five cases which relate to family law. Over the past two years, the ATO has identified six cases involving solicitors who have become bankrupt where the Commissioner of Taxation was a creditor. Of these cases, there were two solicitors who appeared to be using bankruptcy as a means to avoid paying tax. As at December 2003, the ATO is currently pursuing one current case involving the apparent use of serial bankruptcy. The ATO has pursued all cases of apparent serial bankruptcy and all other bankruptcies as creditor in proceedings through the courts. (2) (b) The ATO has and continues to vigorously pursue lodgement of outstanding returns including the use of reminder notices, demands for lodgement, issuing summonses and prosecutions. Defence: Board of Inquiry (Question No. 1981) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 June 2003: (1)(a)Have there been any deaths resulting from activities of the Army Alpine Club; if so, how many, (b) where, and (c) when. (2) Was a Board of Inquiry (BOI) constituted to inquire into the death of Sapper Andrew John Morrison, if so, (a) when, (b) who constituted the BOI, (c) who was the appointing Authority, (d) what were the Terms of Reference, (e) how many days has the BOI sat, (f) when is the BOI expected to deliver its final report, and (g) will the report be made public.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) Did the National Park authorities conduct their own investigation into the death of Sapper Andrew John Morrison; if so, when was the report made available to the next of kin. (4) Did the USA authorities conduct a coronial inquiry; if so (a) when, (b) when were the next of kin advised, (c) were the next of kin given the opportunity to attend the US coronial inquiry, if not, why not, (d) did anyone attend the coronial inquiry on behalf of the ADF; if not, why not. (5) Has it taken 2 years for the next of kin to have been informed of the injuries that led to Sapper Morrison’s death, if so, why. (6) How many submissions have been made to the BOI seeking the evidence of the eight American eyewitnesses to the accident and when were they made. (7) Why has that evidence not been produced over two and a half years later. (8) What are the matters that the President of the BOI has ruled beyond the scope of the Terms of Reference. (9) Have the next of kin been offered legal representation consistent with recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its report into Military Justice Procedures, (10) To date, has this BOI cost $2 million and what are the individual costs, emoluments and disbursements involved in the BOI. (11) What is the anticipated final cost of the BOI. (1) (a) Five. (b) and (c) One in the Nepalese Himalayas in 1981, one in Yosemite USA in 2000 and three in Everest in 2001. (2) Yes. (a) A Board of Inquiry was originally constituted on 28 February 2001 but was suspended because of the unavailability of key witnesses due to operational deployments and another Board of Inquiry. A subsequent Board of Inquiry was appointed on 18 September 2002. (b) The Board of Inquiry consisted of: President – Captain Peter Callaghan, RANR, QC. Members– Commodore George Herron, RAN Retd, and Major Stephen Orr (replaced by Lieutenant Colonel Dennis Littame, Army General Reserve who was appointed to the Board on 5 February 2003). (c) The Board of Inquiry was appointed by the Chief of Army. (d) The Terms of Reference are: 1. Pursuant to the appointment of a Board of Inquiry, you are to assemble at Royal Australian Air Force Base Fairbairn at a time and date determined by the President and at such other places and times as the President may elect for the purpose of inquiring into and reporting on the following matter concerning the Army, namely the incident resulting in the death of 238843 Sapper Andrew John Morrison at Yosemite National Park in the State of California in the United States of America on 3 December 2000 (“the incident”) and the circumstances surrounding it. 2. As part of your inquiry, you are to receive evidence and report on the following matters: a. General Details: (1) the date, time and place of the fall which resulted in the injury to Sapper Morrison (the incident);
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) how the incident occurred and the circumstances surrounding it, i.e., in concise terms, what happened and in what chronological sequence; (3) the activity being conducted by Sapper Morrison and the other members of the Australian Army Alpine Association participating in Exercise BIG WALL 00 (“the exercise”) immediately prior to the incident; (4) the identity and particulars of all participants involved in the exercise and their activities and roles; (5) the cause or causes of the incident; (6) the date, time and place of death of Sapper Morrison; (7) the cause or causes of death of Sapper Morrison; (8) whether Sapper Morrison was on duty; and if so, the specific type of duty being performed at the time of the incident; (9) the details of any injury suffered by any other person as a direct result of the incident, the cause or causes of those injuries and the identity of the personnel concerned; (10) whether any person killed or injured was, at the time of the incident, employed on Continuous Full Time Duty as a member of the Australian Defence Force and was a contributor under the DFRDB or MSBS Acts; and (11) whether or not a claim for compensation from the Commonwealth has been submitted by or on behalf of the dependants of Sapper Morrison. b. Pre-Incident Situation: (1) whether approval for the exercise was given; (2) whether the then existing approval procedures were adequate; (3) the process for selecting personnel to participate in the exercise and its suitability considering the degree of difficulty for climbs of that nature; (4) whether a risk assessment was undertaken for the exercise and, if so, the adequacy of that risk assessment under the then existing protocols and directives; (5) whether the then-existing protocols and directives, relating to risk assessment for the exercise, were adequate; (6) the adequacy of briefings, orders, safety procedures and communications relevant to the exercise; (7) the training regime for personnel selected to participate in the exercise; (8) whether there was any training inadequacy for individuals deployed on the exercise; (9) the qualification, currency of training, depth of experience and medical categories of members participating in the exercise; (10) the condition of members participating in the exercise immediately prior to the incident; (11) the condition and adequacy of the climbing equipment taken on the exercise; and (12) whether the climbing equipment being used by members participating in the exercise had been checked prior to climbing to ensure it was adequate and to proper working order; c. The Incident: (1) the identity and particulars of members involved in the incident and the extent of their involvement; (2) whether the incident was caused or partly caused by: (a) the use of drugs or alcohol; (b) whether there was any requirement for protective clothing and equipment to be worn by Sapper Morrison and, if so, whether he was wearing it and whether it was suitable and sufficient; (c) any equipment malfunction, failure or limitation; (d) any non-compliance with orders, instructions or safety procedures by members participating in the exercise; and (e) any weakness in the system or method of control. d. Post-Incident Situation (1) the actions taken by individuals after the incident; (2) whether the post-incident procedures were appropriate, including: (a) suitability and responsiveness of casualty evacuation; (b) reporting of the incident, including notification of next of kin; and (c) whether trauma debriefing and counselling of affected parties, including Sapper Morrison’s next of kin, and other support was offered. e. Peripheral Matters: (1) Any inadequacies of equipment, training, orders, instructions, procedures, publications etc revealed in the course of the inquiry, which are not regarded as causal factors per se but which the Board considers should be brought to the attention of the Appointing Authority or other military authorities. (2) You are to take evidence from any person or persons who are able to give material information as to the date, time, place, and circumstances of the incident and state the reason if you are unable to obtain evidence from any person involved in the incident. (3) The Board is to make recommendations upon, inter alia, the following: (a) whether any immediate action is required to prevent a recurrence of the incident; (b) actions which should be taken to prevent a recurrence of this occurring, from the same causal factors; incident, or to reduce the probability of another incident; (c) whether the conduct of any member warrants investigation by Service or civilian police; (d) actions which should be taken to eliminate any inadequacies of equipment, training, orders, instructions, procedures, publications, etc revealed in the course of the inquiry which are not regarded as causal factors per se but which the Board considers should be subject to action by the Appointing Authority. (4) The following documents are to be attached to your report: (a) transcript of all evidence, including statements of all relevant witnesses; (b) a copy of the autopsy report; (c) copies of all relevant orders; (d) a copy of the Quick Assessment report; (e) extracts from all relevant publications; (f) as appropriate, photographs of the scene of the incident and damage to equipment; (g) as appropriate, a scale diagram of the scene of the incident; (h) the Instrument of Appointment; and (i) these Terms of Reference. (5) You are to complete your report by 28 February 2003 or, if completion is delayed, submit an interim report on that date and each 28 days thereafter until the report is complete. (e) The Board of Inquiry sat for 101 days. (f) The final report was delivered on 12 August 2003. It was subsequently reviewed by an independent Senior Counsel. The Appointing Authority has considered the conclusions and recommendations of the report. An implementation plan is currenly being developed and preparation made for the release of the report to affected persons and the public. (g) Subject to the approval of the Minister, the Chief of Army intends to release an Executive Summary to the public. Work to enable this to occur is currently under way. (3) Yes. The next of kin were briefed on the National Park Service Investigative Report in October 2001. (4) No. A coroner’s report was made by the Office of the Sheriff, Mariposa. However, a coronial inquiry, as the term is used in Australia, was not conducted. (5) No. Information was made available to the next of kin in the weeks immediately following the incident. (6) There were no American eyewitnesses to the accident. However, the Counsel Assisting advised that submissions were made to the Board on 18 occasions concerning the taking of evidence from material United States witnesses. (7) Most evidence from United States witnesses (not eyewitnesses) was produced to the Board of Inquiry within two and a half years of the death of the member. Five United States witnesses appeared before the Board throughout the week commencing 9 December 2002 and seven United States witnesses appeared before the Board via video link during the period 29 May 2003 to 9 June 2003. (8) There are none. However, the Board did question the Chief of Army as to whether he wished the Board to deal with additional issues outside the Terms of Reference such as the delay in the commencement of the Board. (9) Yes. The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade did not recommend the next of kin be offered legal representation. Legal representation was provided to persons identified as ‘affected persons’. In the scoping stage of the Inquiry, Counsel Assisting identified the next of kin were not affected persons, but that Sapper Andrew Morrison (the deceased) was. Legal representation was therefore provided to represent the interest of Sapper Morrison. The Counsel representing Sapper Morrison took instructions from the next of kin, but the Counsel represented the interests of the deceased. (10) The Army has advised that the cost to date is $2,895,536.80 comprising: Transcription fees $ 105,555.55 Salaries (lawyers) $2,179,981.25 *Sessional fees only Supplier expenses $ 550,000.00 US trip $ 60,000.00 $2,895,536.80 (11) In the order of $2.9 million. National Security: Terrorism (Question No. 2180) Mrs Irwin asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 August 2003: (1) Are the organisations known as Kach and Kahane Chai regarded as derivative organisations of the listed terrorist organisation Hizballah External Security Organisation. (2) Are these organisations known to be active in Australia. (1) No (2) No. Kach and Kahane Chai operate primarily in Israel and the West Bank. Immigration: Unregistered Migration Agents (Question No. 2192) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 August 2003: (1) Since March 1998 how many individuals have been formally investigated by his department following allegations that they have been providing immigration assistance to visa applicants while not being a registered migration agent. (2) How many such cases were subsequently referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) for possible prosecution. (3) How many cases remain under investigation by (a) the department and (b) by the DPP. (4) Against how many individuals has prosecution action been taken and, for each case that has been finalised, what was (a) the state or territory in which the case was launched, (b) the details of the alleged offence(s), (c) the verdict of the court, and (d) the sentence, if any, imposed. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Records relating to the investigation of unregistered migration agents are available from July 2000 when a new recording system came into operation. Since then 464 cases involving allegations of the provision of immigration advice by unregistered migration agents have been examined by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) staff. (2) Of these cases, 13 briefs of evidence have been referred by DIMIA to the DPP for consideration of prosecution action. (3) (a) Ninety eight cases involving allegations of the provision of immigration advice by unregistered agents remain under investigation by the Department. (b) Six matters remain under consideration by the DPP. (4) DIMIA records show that a total of 15 prosecutions since July 2000 have been initiated by the DPP following a submission of a brief of evidence by DIMIA in relation to allegations of unregistered migration practice. The larger number of prosecutions than referrals mentioned in answer (3) above reflects cases initiated prior to July 2000 and finalised since that date. Of these cases, two are still ongoing. The table below provides details held by DIMIA. NSW Recommended charges to DPP included Subpoena not able Warrant Matter ongoing offences against sections 280, 281, 283, to be served, First sworn 234, 245, 244 of the Migration Act 1958 Instance Warrant 05/06/03 sworn NSW One count of an offence against section Conviction 12/10/2000 Fined $500 and ordered to make 282 of the Migration Act 1958 reparation payments of $300 NSW Allegation of unregistered migration Conviction 14/01/2002 Sentenced to two and a half years practice imprisonment, expected release date was 19/10/02. (2) Have any instances been detected where that system has been used to effect money-laundering activities; if so, what were those instances.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister Representing The Minister For Justice And Customs,
theText: the honourable member’s question: (1) Under the provisions of the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 (FTR Act), remittance dealers including operators of alternative remittance systems such as the ‘hawala’ must provide reports of suspicious transactions, significant cash transactions of AU$10,000 or more, and all international funds transfers to the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC). As part of its commitments to the National Illicit Drug Strategy (NIDS) AUSTRAC has focussed significant elements of its regulatory program to the identification, education and monitoring of alternative remittance operators. (2) Access to financial intelligence information collected under the FTR Act is limited to authorised law enforcement and revenue agencies. However, evidence to date suggests that Australia does not have many active ‘hawala’ operators. Taxation: GST Compliance Squad (Question No. 2221) Mr Danby asked the Minister representing the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 August 2003: (1) Can the Minister confirm whether the Government or the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has announced that the ATO would have a specialist GST compliance squad; if so, (a) when and (b) by whom was the announcement made, and (c) what was the content of the announcement. (2) When was the GST compliance squad expected to commence operations and when did it, or when will it, actually commence operations. (3) What was the announced budget for the GST compliance squad and how much has it actually been allocated. (4) In respect of the recruitment for the GST compliance squad, (a) when did the ATO advertise for positions, (b) was the advertising or recruitment done by a private recruitment firm; if so, which one, (c) what was the cost of the advertisements, (d) where were the advertisements placed, (e) what was the closing date for applications, (f) how many applications were received, (g) what was the process for shortlisting applicants, (h) how many applicants were interviewed, (i) when and by whom were interviews conducted, (j) how much did the recruitment process cost (i) in total, (ii) per applicant, and (iii) per interview, (k) what progress has been made since the interviews were conducted, (l) how many applicants, if any, have been offered jobs, and, (m) if no job offers have been made, why and when is it expected that they will be made. (5) Does the Government or the ATO still intend to create a GST compliance squad; if not, why not; if so, will it be necessary to conduct a new recruitment process and, if a new recruitment process is necessary, how much will it cost. (6) Can the Minister confirm that the ATO budgeted for the establishment of the GST compliance squad in the 2003-2004 financial year, but that no money was allocated for this purpose by the Government; if so, (a) how much did the ATO estimate that it would need, (b) why did the Government decide not to allocate it, and (c) when was the ATO informed that it would not receive the funds to establish the GST compliance squad. (7) Is the Minister aware of the claim by the National Tax and Accountants Association that a significant ‘black’ or ‘cash’ economy exists in Australia; if so, (a) can the Minister confirm the claim, (b) is the Minister able to provide an estimate of the size of the ‘black’ economy, and (c) what action does the Government intend to take to reduce it.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer toing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The ATO has had a significant GST compliance capability involving over 2000 field operatives since the commencement of the GST on 1 July 2000. A recent upgrade of the ATO’s serious non-compliance capability was announced in a media release from the Commissioner of Taxation on 30 June 2003. The serious non-compliance area deals with revenue fraud across all taxes administered by the Commissioner of Taxation. The area has drawn on existing resources previously located in the ATO’s Small Business, Excise and Operations areas. (2) to (6) See (1) above. (7) Refer to the Commissioner of Taxation’s media release of 19 August 2003. Crime: Money Laundering (Question No. 2274) (1) In respect of his media release on 7 August 2003 about a reference of powers relating to money laundering, when did he first transmit his request to the State Attorneys-General to refer powers relating to money laundering. (2) How did he transmit that request. (3) When did he first provide the State Attorneys-General with draft legislation providing for the reference of powers. (4) In his request, when did he require the State Attorneys-General to resolve the issue of the reference of powers. (5) Does a decision by the Commonwealth to accept a reference of powers require a decision by Cabinet, or by him acting alone. (6) If the answer to part (5) depends on the circumstances of the case, on what circumstances does it depend. (1) On5 April 2002, Federal, State and Territory Leaders resolved to reform money laundering offences to create effective offences, including a possible reference of powers to the Commonwealth if necessary. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG) discussed this issue at the SCAG meeting on 25-26 July 2002 and referred it to a working group which produced a report for SCAG. On6 August 2003, the former Attorney-General, the Hon Daryl Williams AM QC MP, wrote to State and Territory Attorneys-General confirming the view that a reference of powers is necessary and attaching a draft Bill setting out Commonwealth provisions for such a reference of powers. (2) By letter dated 6 August 2003 to State and Territory Attorneys-General. (3) By letter dated 6 August 2003 to State and Territory Attorneys-General. (4) No deadline was imposed although the Government considers this an important issue that should be resolved as soon as possible. (5) A reference of powers is implemented by legislation passed by the Commonwealth Parliament. The normal government legislation approval processes would be followed. (6) Not applicable.

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Taxation: Bankruptcy Laws (Question No. 2297) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 2003: Further to the answer to question No. 1551 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18166) concerning the taxation affairs of members of the legal profession, will he commit to provide an up-dated report on the Legal Profession Project in the 2002-2003 Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report. Refer to the Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report for 2002-03. Aviation: Airservices Australia (Question No. 2298) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 19 August 2003: (1) Is he aware that the Airservices Australia Reports for 1997-1998 and 1998-1999 provide a Board biography for Ms Gail Burke. (2) Can he confirm that the Board biography for Ms Burke in the report for 1997-1998 states that (a) “Gail Burke heads Macquarie Bank’s Information Services Division”, (b) “She is also an Executive Director of the Bank and its Operations Review and IT Committees”, and (c) “Ms Burke is also a member of the Finance Minister’s IT&T Policy Advisory Committee”. (3) Can he confirm that the Board biography for Ms Burke in the report for 1998-1999 states that (a) “Gail Burke heads Macquarie Bank’s Information Services Division”, and (b) “She is also an Executive Director of the Bank and its Operations Review and IT Committees”. (4) On what date did Ms Burke first become a member of his IT&T Policy Advisory Committee. (5) On what date did Ms Burke cease being a member of his IT&T Policy Advisory Committee. (6) Is he aware that Ms Burke was a member of his IT&T Policy Advisory Committee on 30 July 1997 when the Minister for Transport and Regional Services made a Ministerial Directive on the LongTerm Operating Plan for Sydney Airport pursuant to subsection 16(1) of the Air Services Act 1995. swer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) (a) Yes. (b) Yes. (c) Yes. (3) (a) Yes. (b) Yes. (4) October 1996 (5) August 1997 (6) Yes. I am advised that Ms Burke was a member of ITTPAC when the Minister for Transport and Regional Services made the Ministerial Directive. Ms Burke’s representation on ITTPAC did not represent a conflict of interest in relation to her position at Macquarie Bank. Ms Burke resigned from the Airservices Australia Board with effect from 21 April 2000, which is before the commencement of the privatisation process for Sydney Airport. Immigration: Illegal Workers (Question No. 2305) Mr Danby asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 2003:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following an(1) For each of the years (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, and (h) 2003 to date, how many (i) women have been found working illegally in brothels in Australia, and (ii) how many were under 18 years of age. (2) In respect of the women found working illegally in brothels in Australia, what categories of visas did they hold and what was the total number of visas in each category. (3) How many raids on brothels have been undertaken by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs or the Australian Federal Police. (4) For each of the years (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, and (h) 2003 to date, in how many brothels were women found to be working illegally. (5) How many of the women referred to in part (1) were deported and what is the average length of time from arrest to deportation. (6) Which countries did the women referred to in part (1) come from. (7) How many of the women were interviewed in relation to possible offences committed by their employers. (8) How many brothel owners and managers were (a) investigated for any breaches of the law, (b) charged, and (c) convicted as a result of raids in the period 1996 to date. (9) In relation to the raid on the brothel in Melbourne on Monday 11 August 2003, were any managers or owners investigated or taken into custody in relation to sexual servitude or any other offence. (10) How many brothel owners or managers have been convicted under Commonwealth sexual servitude legislation. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a)-(h) Program Year (i) Found working illegally 1996-97 56 1997-98 200 1998-99 243 1999-2000 190 2000-01 Unavailable 2001-02 Unavailable 2002-03 245 2003-04 (to 31 July 2003) 37 Total 993 Data relating to the number of women found working illegally in brothels in Australia is unavailable for the 2000-01 and 2001-02 program years, due to the introduction of a new computer system in 2000. The limitations in this computer system were rectified in 2002. In relation to part (ii), a 17 year old was located working illegally in the sex industry in July 1996. There were two other cases of minors located working in the sex industry outside of the periods shown above: a 13 year old in 1995 and a 16 year old in September 2003. speaker: Mr Hardgrave
theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous AffairsProgram Year Visa Total Number Temporary Residence 10 Visitor 139 Total 245 2003-04 (to 31July 2003) Bridging 14 Student2 Visitor 21 Total 37 Due to system capabilities, the categories of visas held by women found working illegally in brothels in Australia, and the total number of visas in each category, is unavailable prior to the 2002-03 program year. (3) Due to system capabilities, the number of visits to brothels by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) is unavailable. DIMIA does not maintain statistics for AFP activities. (4) (a)-(h) Due to system capabilities, the number of brothels where women were found working illegally is not available prior to the 2002-03 program year. During 2002-03, approximately 147 brothels were served Illegal Worker Warning Notices (IWWN). These Notices are served on employers when illegal workers are located at the premises. If there are no illegal workers located at the time of the visit, an IWWN is not served. As at 31 July 2003 for the 2003-04 program year, approximately 16 brothels were served IWWNs. (5) Due to system capabilities, data relating to the average length of time from detention to removal of women found working illegally is not available prior to the 2002-03 program year. For 2002-03, the average time from detention to removal (which includes voluntary departures) was 13 days based on 245 detentions. Of the 37 people found working illegally for 2003-04 (up to 31 July 2003), the average time from detention to removal was 4 days. (6) Due to system capabilities, data is not available prior to 1999-2000 program year and, as for (1), for the years 2000-01 and 2001-02. Program Year Found Working Illegally Countries Total 1999-2000 190 British National Overseas1 China (so stated) 1 China, Peoples Republic of 29 Hungary1 Indonesia 4 Korea, Peoples Republic Of1 Korea, Republic of 12 Malaysia 43 Philippines 1 Singapore 2 Thailand 90 United kingdom 2 Vietnam3 Total: 190 2002-03 245 Cambodia, the Kingdom of 1 Program Year Found Working Illegally Countries Total Canada1 China, Peoples Republic of 37 Colombia2 Hungary1 Indonesia 6 Korea, Republic of 37 Malaysia 48 Philippines 2 Thailand 99 United States of America2 Unknown1 Total 245 2003-04 37 China, Peoples Republic of 3 (to 31 July 2003) HKSAR of the PRC 1 Korea, Republic of 1 Malaysia 13 Thailand 19 Total 37 (7) All unlawful non-citizens located working illegally are interviewed in relation to their travel to Australia and circumstances relating to their employment. Any information requiring further investigation is referred to the relevant authorities. This may include information on trafficking, procuring, aiding and abetting, deprivation of liberty and other offences under Commonwealth and State legislation. (8) (a)-(c) DIMIA has specific responsibility for the investigation of offences against the Migration Act 1958 and the Australian Citizenship Act 1948. Allegations under the Migration and Citizenship Acts may be investigated where there is sufficient information to indicate that fraudulent activity has occurred. DIMIA does not have the power to ‘charge’ offenders; instead, a DIMIA investigation may proceed to a ‘summons’ issued by the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions. There is no specific crime under the Migration Act that relates to the employment of unlawful noncitizens or to the ownership or management of brothels. Therefore, there have been no investigations finalised by DIMIA on the basis of an individual’s ownership or management of a brothel. Investigations are not recorded in DIMIA systems by the occupation of the individual under investigation but rather by offence and the suspect’s name. The Department has, however, provided assistance to other agencies in their investigation of matters relating to the sex industry. The Department is aware that some of these investigations have resulted in the prosecution of brothel owners and managers by these agencies. Some of these persons may have been involved in DIMIA compliance activity during the period specified; others may be under investigation for other offences such as making false statements and false representations in relation to visa applications. (9) The AFP has carriage of the investigation of people trafficking and sexual servitude offences with DIMIA playing a key role in identifying and referring people trafficking matters to the AFP. A matter has been referred to the AFP for investigation as a result of the operation that took place in Melbourne on Monday 11 August 2003. (10) This is the responsibility of the AFP and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions. Aviation: Airport Noise Levels (Question No. 2335) September 2003: (1) Is he familiar with the sixth message of the Community Panel Report to Sydney Airport Corporation in June 2003 recommending that the residential noise insulation program be expanded in line with the impacts of airport expansion. (2) What is the current status and level of activity of the residential noise insulation project. (3) Is he able to say whether there will be any future expansion of the insulation area; if so, where is that expansion likely to take place. (1) I understand the Community Panel Report forms part of Sydney Airport Corporation Limited’s consultation process for the preliminary draft Master Plan. I will consider the draft Master Plan in due course. (2) Of the 4085 eligible residences included in the programme, 4060 have now had insulation work completed, with work on the remaining residences nearing completion. (3) No. Boundaries of the residential insulation area are reviewed on an annual basis, based on annual Australian Noise Exposure Index maps for the airport. Any expansion in the insulation area would be dependent on changes in the relevant noise exposure contour lines, which might occur in the future as a result of aircraft operations at the airport. Taxation: Reef Tax (Question No. 2370) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 September 2003: (1) Did the Government, between 1998 to present, make assurances to marine operators on the Great Barrier Reef in North Queensland, including the Association of Marine Park Tourism Operators (AMPTO), that the GST would not apply to the Reef tax; if so, on what authority were such undertakings made. (2) Was he aware of these undertakings at the time; if not, when did he become aware of them. (3) Were any representations made to him to support the undertaking of non-compliance with the GST legislation. (1) to (3) The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer advised the Association of Marine Park Tourism Operators (AMPTO) that the Environmental Management Charge (EMC) would be listed in the Treasurer’s Determination relating to Division 81 of the GST Act. This Determination lists those taxes, fees and charges that are not subject to the GST. The advice issued 5 June 2000, and the Determination issued 1 July 2000. Taxation: Reef Tax (Question No. 2371) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 September 2003: (1) Has the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) determined that the GST applies to the Reef tax; if so, has the ATO commenced action against marine operators who failed to collect the GST payable on the Reef tax since 1999.

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister For Transport And Regional Services, Upon Notice, On 8
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) Was he aware that only one or two operators had actually collected the GST on the Reef tax; if so, what action did he take in response to this situation. (3) On whose authority did the ATO decide not to continue with action to recover the GST and was he aware of the decision made by the ATO. (4) Did he or any other member of the Government direct or otherwise influence the ATO to discontinue action to recover the GST which had not been collected on the Reef tax. (5) Is it the case that the ATO has written to operators advising that the GST should be collected on the Reef tax effective from 1 September 2003; if so, (a) on what basis was this decision made, (b) who made it, and (c) how was the date of 1 September determined. (6) Is a differential application of the liability to collect and forward the GST supported by the Government. (7) Will the approach adopted for the application of the GST to the Reef Tax be applied to other similar cases as they come to the ATO’s notice. (1) GST does not apply to the Environmental Management Charge (EMC) paid by the marine operators to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. (2) GST does not apply to the EMC. However, GST applies to the final price for tourism services supplied by a tourist operator. When it became clear that only a few operators were correctly accounting for their GST obligations in this regard, the ATO worked with the industry to improve their knowledge of the GST requirements to assure future compliance. (3) to (4) The decision not to recover past tax was taken by the Commissioner under section 63 of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 (TAA Act) which confers upon him the general administration of indirect tax laws. (5) GST does not apply to the EMC. The ATO has worked closely with the industry to ensure that all operators are aware of their obligations. This included advice that the total price charged for tourism services is subject to GST, and that all operators would be required to account for tax on this basis from 1 September 2003. (a) to (b) This decision was taken by the Commissioner under section 63 of the AA which confers upon him the general administration of indirect tax laws. (c) The Commissioner advises that 1 September 2003 was considered to be the earliest date by which the ATO could ensure that all of the industry members were aware of their obligations and could reasonably be expected to have restructured their advertising, pricing and accounting systems to properly reflect their GST obligations. (6) The Commissioner has the general administration power to allow him to take into account the circumstances of particular cases in delivering a fair and reasonable administration of the indirect tax laws. (7) The Commissioner has advised that he will continue to make his administrative decisions based on the circumstances applicable in each particular case and in accordance with the powers conferred upon him under the taxation law. Employment: Post Program Monitoring Survey (Question No. 2396) Mr Albanese asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 15 September 2003:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Using the Post Program Monitoring Survey would he provide details of the employment and educational outcomes achieved by jobseekers exiting Intensive Assistance for the second time during ESC2. (2) Would he also provide these details for jobseekers exiting Intensive Assistance for the third time. (1) Post Programme Monitoring (PPM) survey data show that, three months after leaving assistance, 41.9 per cent of jobseekers who participated in Intensive Assistance for a second time were in employment, while 8.5 per cent were in education and training places. (2) PPM survey data show that, three months after leaving assistance, 42.4 per cent of jobseekers who participated in Intensive Assistance for a third time were in employment, while 7.6 per cent were in education and training places. Human Rights: China (Question No. 2404) Mr Organ asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 2003: (1) What was the outcome of the 7th Australia-China Human Rights Dialogue which took place in China and Tibet on 28 July 2003. (2) Did the delegation meet with any political prisoners and visit any prisons in Tibet. (3) Is he able to say what has become of the Panchen Lama, Gedhun Choekyi Nyima, who is recognised by the Dalai Lama and who has not been seen by any outsider since 1995. (4) Did the delegation raise the issue of the Panchen Lama during its recent visit, or has Australia raised the issue at any other time. (5) Will he explain the Government’s position on the ongoing dialogue between China and the representatives of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. (6) Did the Government ever consider appointing a Tibet Co-ordinator to facilitate dialogue, as the United States of America has done. (7) What is the Government’s position on the recent meeting between the Dalai Lama and the President of the United States on 9 September 2003. (8) Will the Government be raising the issue of Tibet with the President of the People’s Republic of China during his forthcoming visit to Australia. (1) Australia was able to raise its full range of concerns about the human rights situation in China, including those that relate to Tibet. The dialogue agreed on the next set of projects to be undertaken as part of the bilateral Human Rights Technical Cooperation Program, including reaching agreement to extend the Program to Tibet. China briefed Australia on further steps it was taking to minimise the potential for human rights abuses. The delegation passed to the Chinese a list of cases of individuals of concern. Nine individuals whose cases we had raised with the Chinese during and since the last round of the Dialogue in 2002 have since been released. (2) No. (3) The Chinese delegation advised that Gedhun Choekyi Nyima, the boy identified by the Dalai Lama as the reincarnation of the Panchen Lama, is well and being given all necessary care and attention, including education, and his parents have asked that he not be disturbed. (4) Yes. His case has been raised at all sessions of the bilateral Human Rights Dialogue. (5) The Australian Government supports and encourages dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese leaders.

Foreign Affairs: Afghanistan (Question No. 2414) 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2152 (Hansard, 9 September 2003, page 19077), is he aware that a lead lawyer in the American Bar Association’s project to draft labour legislation for Afghanistan was supplied by the American law firm, Dechert. The International Labour Organisation’s offer has been accepted. Transport: Rail Security (Question No. 2434) 18 September 2003: What steps has he taken since 11 September 2001 to (a) enhance the security of (i) railroad infrastructure, (ii) major rail facilities, and (iii) key rail hubs, (b) enhance the security of passengers travelling by rail, and (c) ensure that cargo transported by rail does not pose a threat to Australia’s national security. Responsibility for the rail system in Australia rests with the State and Territory Governments. Commonwealth involvement in the operation of rail infrastructure is limited to the intercapital standard gauge network managed by the Australian Rail Track Corporation. The remainder of the commercial rail system is operated by either State Government entities or the private sector. In these circumstances the security of rail infrastructure, the associated facilities, hubs, passengers and freight is primarily the responsibility of the relevant State and Territory Government entities and the private sector rail owners and operators. However, rail infrastructure and facilities are being incorporated in the development of the Australian Transport Council’s National Transport Security Strategy together with other land transport infrastructure. The strategy will assist transport operators to incorporate information about the threat from terrorism into security assessment and planning processes. The State and Territory Governments have also identified critical transport infrastructure including elements of the rail network as part of the National Critical Infrastructure Protection Process. This process involves developing security measures for the identified infrastructure that can be implemented to respond to changes in the nature or level of threat. Government officials have also been working with the

(1)-(2) Refer to Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report 2002-03. The Australian Taxation Office’s approach to industry codes is contained in the answer to Question number 1459 tabled on 29 May 2003. Australian Taxation Office: Garnishee Orders (Question No. 2448) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: Further to the answer to question No. 1653 (Hansard, 8 September 2003, page 18973), what is the amount of money obtained by the Commissioner of Taxation for, or on account of, a debtor from third parties in each of the financial years ended 1997 to 2003. The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) does not maintain records of amounts of money obtained, for or on account of debtors, from third parties. Taxation: Legal Profession (Question No. 2451) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1597 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18168), how is the Commissioner of Taxation encouraging debate in the community and within the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) so that he might better balance resources given to him by the Government to achieve the greatest compliance with taxation laws especially as they relate to members of the legal profession. (2) Is the ATO adequately staffed and adequately financially resourced; if not, what is the Government doing to assist the Commissioner of Taxation maximise his opportunities to collect the revenue due to the Commonwealth. (3) How are compliance decisions made by the Australian Taxation Office and the Commissioner of Taxation. (4) Has the Commissioner of Taxation sought feedback from the staff of the Australian Taxation Office regarding their concerns; if so, (a) what was the nature of that feedback, and (b) has there been any negative feedback; if so, what are the details. (1) The Commissioner of Taxation’s Compliance Program 2003/04 describes the risks of the selfassessment system and how the resources of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) are used to treat
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
