speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:them. In publishing these risks and describing what is being done about them, the ATO is demonstrating that the tax system is being managed in an open and accountable way, and that it is balancing education and enforcement functions in a way that is acceptable to the community and sustainable in the long term. The Commissioner invites feedback on how the tax system is being managed. As well, whenever possible, the ATO engages community representatives and other specialists in decision-making forums, including rulings panels and accountability and integrity committees. The Commissioner has identified the legal profession as one of a number of areas of risk requiring attention, and is utilising a range of education, enforcement and consultation strategies to effect improvements in compliance. (2) Yes. The ATO has been funded in accordance with the Output Pricing Agreement, which provides an increased funding base of $1,885.5 million over the three years, 2003-04, 2004-05 and 2005-06. The Agreement includes funding for specific strategies outlined in the Compliance Program 2003/04. (3) The ATO’s compliance strategies seek to maximise the number of people who choose to comply by making it as easy as possible for people to understand and meet their obligations and by ensuring there are approaches in place to deter non-compliance. Risk assessment is a key factor in determining the nature and timing of activities undertaken. The ATO also seeks to ensure its responses are appropriate and proportionate to non-compliance activities it detects, including the firmest possible enforcement response to those who deliberately set out to avoid their obligations. (4) As mentioned in QoN 1597, the Commissioner has not received complaints about the legal profession from staff via the “ATOconcern” service. Taxation: Income Tax (Question No. 2452) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1641 (Hansard, 15 September 2003, page 19411), what is the breakdown of occupations listed as ‘Accounting services’ under which 18 percent pay the top marginal tax rate, in particular, is it possible to break down this group into ‘Accountants’, ‘Accounting services’, ‘Auditing services’, ‘Bookkeeping services’ and ‘Tax agents’; if not, why not. (2) What is the reason for aggregating such disparate sub-business industries under global BIC listings such as ‘Accounting services’. (3) How is public scrutiny facilitated by such BIC aggregations. (4) How is the public to know whether a particular sub-business industry group or BIC group is paying their correct share of taxation. (5) Will he consider an inquiry into the reasons why the providers of ‘Accounting services’ have such a low percentage of their business industry population paying the top marginal tax rate; if so, when; if not, why not. (1) The answer to Question No. 1641 on accounting services relates to ANZSIC industry code 78420. Auditing services, Bookkeeping services and Tax agents. As these sub-industries are all grouped into this industry code, it is not possible to conduct a separate analysis on each of the sub-industry groups within the code. (2) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) industry coding regime is based upon the four digit Australian and New Zealand Standard Industry Classification (ANZSIC) system which is maintained by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). However, the ATO adds a fifth digit of
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:ATO ANZSIC for internal purposes. This fifth digit is utilised by the ATO when a business requirement is identified which necessitates a finer disaggregation of the ABS ANZSIC. (3) The industry aggregations available to the ATO are at least as disaggregated as those maintained by the ABS (Australian Standard). (4) The ATO regularly undertakes risk assessment activities across the entire taxpayer population, and this sub-industry group is included in this process. This process informs the ATO’s active compliance program which aims to ensure that all taxpayers are paying the correct amount of tax. (5) The ATO will continue to examine the tax compliance of professions, including those in the accounting services sub-industry population. Aviation: Airport Noise Levels (Question No. 2462) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: (1) Is he aware of changes to flight paths for departures and arrivals at Sydney Airport that will bring properties in the Sydney Basin currently not eligible for noise insulation under the Sydney Airport Noise Insulation Program (SANIP) within that program, if so, what are the details. (2) What effect will the changes in flight paths have on the ANEF Contour lines currently used to determine the applicability of Australian Standard AS2021 to particular properties. (3) Are revised ANEF Contour line maps publicly available for noise affected properties under the flight paths of aircraft arrivals and departures for Sydney Airport; if so, where can these revised maps be obtained; if not, when will these maps become available. (4) Will any part of the electoral division of Lowe become eligible for noise insulation under the (1) No. (2) See answer to question (1). (3) Yes. Copies are available from Sydney Airport Corporation Limited. (4) It is considered unlikely that any properties within Lowe would meet the eligibility criteria for noise insulation under the Sydney Airport Noise Insulation Programme in the foreseeable future. Government Departments: Legal Services (Question No. 2464) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: Further to answers to questions Nos 1620 to 1635 and 1637 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18283) what are the Executive officers of the Minister’s departments and agencies doing to ensure that they do not retain the services of any barrister or solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt. On 21 March 2001 the former Attorney-General wrote to me to ask that my Department and agencies within my portfolio take steps not to brief counsel who have become insolvent to avoid their taxation obligations. Following this I issued instructions to my Department and portfolio agencies to comply with the Attorney-General’s request. I should point out that Departmental officers do not conduct litigation. Litigation, which includes the engagement of counsel, is conducted on the Department’s behalf by its panel of legal service providers. Members of this panel have been advised of the Attorney-General’s requirements as to counsel. I am not aware of any policy as to the engagement of solicitors.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Government Departments: Legal Services (Question No. 2469) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: Further to the answers to questions Nos 1620 to 1635 and 1637 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18283) what are the Chief Executive Officers of the Minister’s departments and agencies doing to ensure that they do not retain the services of any barrister or solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt. The Commonwealth policy in relation to such matters, which is set out in the letter of 21 March 2001 from the Commonwealth Attorney-General to all Ministers, is intended to ensure that Commonwealth Departments and agencies do not engage counsel ‘who use insolvency as a means of avoiding tax’. The policy is not directed at preventing the briefing of all counsel who are, or have been, insolvent. Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade DFAT has contracts with two commercial law firms and the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) to provide legal services to the Department. Specifically, the Deeds of Standing Offer require each legal service provider to: have financial viability provide appropriately skilled and qualified legal practitioners have a good reputation and standing within the legal service community. In addition, all legal work done by, or on behalf, of DFAT must be done in accordance with the Attorney-General’s Legal Service Directions on Counsel Engagement. These Directions bind Commonwealth agencies which are subject to the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997. The Attorney General could provide further detail concerning these policies. AusAID AusAID has Period Offer contracts with two commercial law firms to provide legal practitioners. In addition, the Australian Government Solicitor also provides legal practitioners under a Record of Understanding. The Period Offer Deed and the ROU require the above organisations to provide appropriately skilled and qualified legal practitioners. The various Australian legal admissions boards are required by legislation to determine whether applicants for practising certificates are of good fame and character and fit to be admitted. The AusAID contracts have similar requirements. Under the legislation, all applicants for admission to practise must advise the admissions board(s) of any actions (including bankruptcy) which may impact the Board’s decision. Following the issue of a certificate, legal practitioners are required to advise their Board of any action which could cause the Board to review a decision to issue a certificate. The Board is then required to determine whether or not to cancel or suspend a certificate. Personnel without a practising certificate are therefore not “appropriately skilled and qualified” legal practitioners and would not be acceptable personnel under the Contracts or the ROU. Australia Japan Foundation The Australia-Japan Foundation generally uses the in-house services of officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's Legal Branch for its legal requirements. For occasional other services, the Foundation employs the services of a major domestic legal firm. That firm was recently subject to an exhaustive tender process to provide specialist legal services to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. As part of that process, the firm had to satisfy Australian Government procurement requirements, including on financial viability and probity, that would minimise the risk of the Foundation engaging a barrister or solicitor who had previously been made bankrupt.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Export Finance and Insurance Corporation EFIC maintains standing agreements with several commercial law firms to provide legal services to the Corporation as required. Typically, EFIC engages counsel on the advice and recommendation of those firms. In exceptional circumstances, EFIC may engage counsel directly. EFIC understands that at the time of a person’s application for a practising certificate from the Law Society or Bar Association in New South Wales (as applicable), and upon application for annual renewal of that certificate, the applicant is required to disclose to the relevant authority any action that could cause the authority to review a decision to issue or renew a certificate, including whether the applicant is an undischarged bankrupt. The authority then determines whether to issue, cancel or suspend a practising certificate or to impose conditions on its renewal. EFIC understands that similar considerations apply in other States and Territories and by virtue of legislation governing the mutual recognition of professional qualifications. Legal service providers who do not hold a practising certificate, or who hold a practising certificate on conditions of the type described above, are not appropriately skilled and qualified legal practitioners for EFIC’s purposes and the Corporation would therefore not seek to retain them. Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Government Departments: Legal Services (Question No. 2474) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: Further to the answers to questions Nos 1620 to 1635 and 1637 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18168) what are the Chief Executive Officers of the Minister’s departments and agencies doing to ensure that they do not retain the services of any barrister or solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt. swer to the honourable member’s question: The Department and portfolio agencies use their panel firms of solicitors to instruct barristers where required. Engagement of barristers is done in accordance with the Attorney-General’s Legal Services Directions on Engagement of Counsel. The Australian Government policy in relation to such matters, was set out in the letter of 21 March 2001 from the then Attorney-General to all Ministers and is intended to ensure that departments and agencies do not engage counsel who use insolvency as a means of avoiding tax. The policy is not directed at preventing the briefing of all counsel who are, or have been, insolvent. The Department’s Deed of Standing offer with its panel of legal service providers stipulates that panel firms must inform the Department of matters relating to the financial capacity of the service provider or any sub-contractor, such as a barrister, which may affect their ability to perform obligations under the Deed. The Deed further provides that the Department may terminate the firms’ services in the event of insolvency. Our agreement with panel firms also stipulates that they must comply with relevant professional standards and Commonwealth and Departmental policies. ComSuper and the Commonwealth Grants Commission (CGC) utilise the services of the Australian Government Solicitor exclusively in respect of all legal matters. The PSS and CSS Boards use a select number of leading national law firms to provide legal advice. These firms are selected and briefed on the basis of their expertise in investment, superannuation and related matters. The Boards have not briefed counsel directly on a matter in recent years-this would

The Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) retains a panel of legal advisers who have been subjected to a rigorous evaluation and selection process. The law firms appointed to the AEC’s Legal Panel were required to confirm the bona fides of all legal personnel assigned to providing legal advice and assistance to the AEC. It is a requirement under the terms and conditions of the National Legal Panel contract that this requirement be maintained, particularly when, or if, a member of the nominated legal team is replaced or additional personnel are added. Prior to confirmation of selection to the legal panel each law firm was also subjected to a fiduciary check. Government Departments: Legal Services (Question No. 2475) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: Further to the answers to questions Nos 1620 to 1635 and 1637 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18283) what are the Chief Executive Officers of the Minister’s departments and agencies doing to ensure that they do not retain the services of any barrister or solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt. The Attorney-General’s advice of 2001 regarding the engagement of barristers using insolvency to avoid their taxation obligations was circulated to the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and portfolio agencies. The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and portfolio agencies use reputable legal firms and undertake appropriate due diligence in the process of procuring legal services. The Department has also circulated the Attorney-General’s advice to its Legal Services provider. Employment: Job Network (Question No. 2499) Mr Albanese asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on Tuesday, 7 October 2003: What proportion of jobseekers is expected to exit the Job Network within the first 3 months of being registered with a provider. The Department currently estimates that the proportion of jobseekers that will exit the Job Network within the first 3 months of being registered is 37 per cent. This is subject to ongoing adjustments and reviews in light of experience and changing labour market conditions. Phillips Fox: Request for Tender (Question No. 2510) (1) Was Phillips Fox awarded a tender to conduct a review of the Copyright Amendment (Digital Agenda) Act 2000. (2) What did the Government require of organisations submitting tenders, in relation to (a) disclosure of conflicts of interest, and (b) action to address conflicts of interest. (3) Did Phillips Fox disclose any actual or potential conflicts of interest; if so, (a) what conflicts did it disclose, and (b) what action did Phillips Fox and the Government take to address such conflicts. (4) Is the Minister or his department aware that LEF Interactive Pty Ltd has been a client of solicitors at Phillips Fox; if so, when did they become aware. (5) Is the Minister or his department aware of the relationship between LEF Interactive Pty Ltd and Kazaa; if so, when did they become aware. (6) Does LEF Interactive Pty Ltd have an interest in the outcome of the review. (7) What steps has the Government taken to ensure that the review is not discredited by actual or potential conflicts of interest. (1) The contract awarded to Phillips Fox was to undertake independent research and analysis of key aspects of the Copyright Amendment (Digital Agenda) Act from a legal, economic and technical perspective. This research and analysis will inform the Government’s broader review of those reforms. (2) (a) Specification of actual or perceived conflicts of interest was a mandatory criterion of the Request for Tender (RFT). (b) Where circumstances existed that could give rise to either an actual or perceived conflict of interest the tenderer was required to include in their tender a proposed management plan for dealing with each actual or perceived conflict. (3) (a) Phillips Fox complied with the conflict of interest requirements in the RFT and satisfied the Tender Evaluation Team that they could carry out the contracted services independently of stakeholder interests. The information that the Department holds in this regard was supplied in confidence. The names of Phillips Fox clients are subject to legal professional privilege. Phillips Fox also stated that the firm operated a library that fell within the definition of section 18 of the Copyright Act 1968, which may be affected by any decision, whether as a result of the review or otherwise, to exclude ‘corporate libraries’ from the operation of that Act. (b) Phillips Fox specified a management plan in its tender to deal with any actual or perceived conflict of interest. Among other things, Phillips Fox explicitly undertook not to act for any person, or provide any other assistance, in connection with any submission or possible submission to the review, without the Attorney-General’s Department’s prior written consent. The contract between Phillips Fox and the Commonwealth also contains provisions to deal with any conflicts of interest that may arise during the performance of the contract.

The Department became aware that a relationship exists between Sharman Networks Limited and LEF Interactive Pty Ltd through media reporting of court actions in the United States initiated by the film industry in late 2002 in relation to peer-to-peer filesharing software. (6) There have been over 70 submissions from a diverse range of stakeholders made in response to the Issues Papers. This is indicative that many organisations are interested in the outcome of the review. (7) In addition to conflict of interest requirements set out above, the required methodology for undertaking the contract services included a number of mandatory components designed to ensure the integrity of the review. Tenderers were required to include in their methodology a process for reporting regularly to the Attorney-General’s Department. Methodologies were also required to include the preparation of issues papers and the holding of public forums to facilitate discussion of the issues raised. All parties with an interest in the consultant’s analysis have an opportunity to participate in the public consultation phase and to contribute submissions to the review. Provision was made for all non-confidential submissions to be made available online. speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer toLoaded TEU Empty TEU Total Port State Per Year Per Day Per Year Per Day Per Year Per Day (vii) Port Adelaide SA 40,879 112 24,765 68 65,644 180 * * * (viii) Gladstone QLD 7 107 114 (ix) Townsville QLD 3279 9 4852 13 8,131 22 (x) Kwinana WA 0 0 0 0 0 0 (xi) Port Botany NSW Included in Sydney figure * * (xii) Port Hedland WA 14 0 0 14 (xiii) Bunbury WA 0 0 0 0 0 0 * * (xiv) Port Kembla NSW 140 0 0 140 (xv) Geelong VIC 0 0 0 0 0 0 * * (xvi) Portland VIC 11 0 0 11 (xvii) Launceston TAS 6045 17 1936 5 7,981 22 * The number of containers that pass through lower volume ports on a daily basis can vary significantly and therefore any figures provided would be arbitrary. For example, the 14 import containers that passed through Port Hedland in the 2002/03 financial year all arrived in one shipment. The 11 import containers that passed through Portland in the same period arrived in two shipments. The industry standard is to record container statistics in twenty foot equivalent (TEU) unit terms rather than the actual number of containers. Most international containers are either 20 ft (1 TEU) or 40 ft (2 TEUs). On average, the number of containers is equivalent to 75 per cent of the number of TEUs. Customs records do not distinguish between containers received at Port Botany and Port Jackson but record the containers for both ports together under Sydney. As such, figures are not available separately for Port Botany. Kwinana is not a port that facilitates containerised cargo. (2) (a), (b) All cargo imported to Australia, including containerised cargo, is screened by Customs. The new Container Examination Facilities have not been operational for a 12-month period as yet. The figures provided represent activity from start-up date, which includes a ramp-up period. The contents of 10 per cent of the containers x-rayed in the Container Examination Facilities are unpacked and physically examined. The Melbourne Container Examination Facility examined 17,125 containers in the December 2002 to October 2003 period. Since August 2003, Melbourne has averaged 465 containers per week. The Sydney Container Examination Facility examined 13,140 containers in the March 2003 to October 2003 period. Since August 2003, Sydney has averaged 479 containers per week. The Brisbane Container Examination Facility examined 6523 containers in the February 2003 to October 2003 period. Since August 2003, Brisbane has averaged 278 containers per week. The targets for the Container Examination Facilities, when fully operational are: Sydney and Melbourne -100 containers per day, or 26,000 containers per year in each port. Brisbane 60 containers per day, or 15,600 containers per year. Fremantle 50 containers per day, or 13,000 containers per year. Container examinations in other ports for the 2002/03 financial year were: In the Port of Adelaide, 351 containers were examined, or around one container per day. In the Port of Townsville, 158 containers were examined. In the Port of Launceston, 115 containers were examined. In the Port of Newcastle, 42 containers were examined. Containers imported into Port Kembla, Port Hedland, Portland and Gladstone were screened but were not selected any for x-ray or for physical examination. No containers were imported into Geelong, Kwinana, Bunbury or Haypoint. Telstra: Pensioner Concession Schemes (Question No. 2513) Mr Tanner asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 7 October 2003: (1) In respect of Telstra’s new low income package “access for everyone”, (a) which categories of pensioner are eligible for concessional rates and which are not, (b) have any categories of pensioner previously eligible for a concession been excluded from the new package, and (c) can he explain why was it decided that the categories of pensioner not eligible for a concession would not be eligible. (2) In respect of Telstra’s claim on its website that the new package includes a clarification of the definition of an eligible pensioner, (a) how has the definition been clarified, and (b) exactly how does the old definition differ from the new definition. (3) Why was it decided that pensioners would no longer be eligible for a discount on new telephone connections and what other discounts, rebates or other advantages available on the old package are not available on the new package. (4) What was the cost per annum of the old package for people on low incomes and how does this compare with the almost $160 million worth of services claimed to be provided in “access for everyone”. (5) In respect of obligations on Telstra to advertise and publicise its pensioner concession schemes, (a) what obligations, if any, does the Government currently impose, and (b) has any review been undertaken in regards to Telstra compliance with these requirements; if so, what was the outcome of that review or reviews. (6) Are eligible pensioners informed of Telstra’s concession scheme when they apply for their pension at Centrelink. (7) Is the Minister able to say whether all eligible pensioners with a Telstra account are receiving a pensioner discount, if not, (a) why not, and (b) what portion of eligible pensioners are estimated to be receiving a pensioner discount. (1) (a) Telstra has advised that the following persons are eligible for Telstra’s pensioner concessions: (i) non-business customers who are directly billed by Telstra for line rental and local calls; and (ii) hold a current Pensioner Concession Card issued by Centrelink or Department of Veterans’ Affairs (DVA); and (iii) are recipients of any one of the following payment types where valid for 12 months in a full year of issue: (A) Age Pension, card code AGE or AGE BLIND; (B) Carer Payment recipient, card code CAR; (C) Disability Support Pension, card code DSP or DSP BLIND; (D) Mature Age Allowance, card code MAA; (E) Mature Age Partner Allowance, card code MPA;
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(F) Newstart Allowance (age 60 and over), card code NSA; (G) Newstart Mature Age Allowance, card code NMA; (H) Parenting Payment (Partnered) (age 60 and over), card code PPP; (I) Parenting Payment (Single), card code PPS (PCC version only, not HCC); (J) Partner Allowance (age 60 and over), card code PTA; (K) Sickness Allowance (age 60 and over), card code SAL; (L) Special Benefit (age 60 and over), card code SPL; (M) Widow Allowance (age 60 and over), card code WA; (N) WidowB Pension, card code WID; and (O) Wife Pension, card code WA, WFD, WFW. (b) Telstra has advised that, from 1 January 2003, persons in the following categories have not been eligible for the pensioner concessions unless they were deemed eligible for the concessions by Telstra prior to this date: (i) Australian war widow or widower; (ii) Special rate disability pensioner; (iii) Extreme (or intermediate) rate disability pensioner; (iv) Extreme disablement adjustment disability pensioner; and (v) Increased rate disability pensioner. (c) Telstra has advised that the change in eligibility criteria was made to align eligibility with the pensioner category types use by Centrelink and DVA. (2) (a) See answer to part (1) (c) of the question. (b) Telstra has advised that, prior to 1 January 2003, the following persons were eligible for the pensioner concessions: (i) non-business customers who were directly billed by Telstra for line rental and local calls; and (ii) held a current Centrelink Pensioner Concession Card (including an Age Pension, a Disability Support Pension or a Carer Payment recipient) or a DVA Pensioner Concession Card, or were one of the following: (A) Australian war widow or widower; (B) Special rate disability pensioner; (C) Extreme (or intermediate) rate disability pensioner; (D) Extreme disablement adjustment disability pensioner; or (E) Increased rate disability pensioner. (3) Telstra has advised that pensioners remain eligible for a discount on new telephone connections. Telstra advised that all discounts, rebates and other advantages available to eligible pensioners under the arrangements that existed prior to 1 July 2002 remain available and, in some areas, have been significantly increased. (4) Telstra has advised that it regards the cost or value of discounts, rebates and other advantages to pensioners under the arrangements that existed prior to 1 July 2002 as being commercially sensitive information. Telstra has therefore declined to provide this information. (5) (a) The Government requires Telstra, under clause 22 of the Carrier Licence Conditions (Telstra Corporation Limited) Declaration 1997, to have a package of products for low-income consumers and a marketing plan for making consumers aware of the package. (b) The Australian Communications Authority (ACA) is responsible for monitoring Telstra’s compliance with its licence condition, on an ongoing basis. ACA’s observer status on the Lowincome Measures Assessment Committee (LIMAC), which comprises representatives of welfare organisations and has responsibilities in relation to the form and marketing of the Telstra low-income package, assists the ACA in carrying out this responsibility. Clause 22 of the licence declaration also provides for an annual report to be provided by LIMAC to the Minister on the effectiveness of the low-income package and its marketing by Telstra. The first full report is expected to be provided in early 2004. The annual report to the Minister will further assist the ACA in its ongoing role of monitoring and enforcing compliance with the licence condition. (6) Centrelink has advised that it does not advertise Telstra pensioner concessions specifically as it may be considered to be discriminating among telecommunications providers. However, Centrelink customers are encouraged, for example when they receive their Pensioner or Health Concession Card, to contact service providers to see if they offer concessions. Centrelink also advised that the ‘Guide to Pensioner Concessions’ booklet, includes a section ‘Telephone Concessions’ which states that ‘Upon application, some telephone service providers offer concessions. Cardholders should contact their telephone service provider’. (7) (a) Telstra has advised that its pensioner concessions are available on application by eligible pensioners. The concessions are not automatically applied. Telstra advised that, as at 31 August 2003, 1,315,314 Telstra customers were receiving the pensioner concessions. (b) Information provided by Telstra, Centrelink and the DVA does not enable the calculation of the proportion of eligible pensioners that have taken up the concessions or rebates offered. This would require further information on: (i) numbers of pensioners holding the relevant payment cards; (ii) of these, the numbers with a fixed telephone service who are Telstra customers for line rentals and local calls; and (iii) numbers of payment card holders living in households that receive the Telstra concessions or rebates. Defence: National Service Medal (Question No. 2518) Ms O’Byrne asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 October 2003: (1) To date, how many applications for the Anniversary of National Service Medals (ANSM) have been received from applicants in the electoral division of Bass. (2) How many ANSMs have been issued to applicants residing in the electoral division of Bass. (3) What is the (a) average and (b) longest processing time for an ANSM application. (4) Is the Minister aware of complaints being made about the length of processing time and what steps is the Minister taking to ensure efficient and speedy processing of ANSM applications.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Identification of applicants within the electoral division of Bass is not able to be computer generated as electorate information is not a required data field for processing applications. A manual search would require diversion of resources now utilised to process applications. (2) As indicated in part (1), applicants within electoral divisions are not identified. (3) & (4) The transfer of the ANSM assessment functions from Melbourne to Canberra occurred in May 2003. Since then the Directorate of Honours and Awards have implemented a number of initiatives and made significant progress in dealing with the backlog of applications. With just over 2000 applications remaining, Defence is on target to reduce the timeframe from receipt of an application to despatch of the medal to one month by January 2004. Taxation: Family Tax Benefit (Question No. 2522) Mr Gibbons asked the Minister representing the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 October 2003: (1) Is the Minister aware that there is a consent form on the back of the 2003 Tax Return for Individuals to authorise the ATO to use part or all of a taxpayer’s 2002-2003 tax refund to repay the 2003 Family Tax Benefit overpayment to their spouse. (2) Is the Minister also aware that a taxpayer must obtain their spouse’s permission to quote their CRN. (3) Can the Minister explain how the ATO is able to access a taxpayer’s tax refund if the taxpayer does not sign the authorisation. (4) If the ATO is lawfully able to access a taxpayer’s tax refund, could the Minister explain why the taxpayer is required to complete the authorisation. answer to the honourable member’s question as follows: (1) Yes, there is a consent form on the back of the 2003 Tax Return for Individuals to repay a spouse’s family tax benefit overpayment from their tax refund. Consent is contained in sec 93 of the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Act 1999. This allows for any person who is entitled to an income tax refund to give consent to use that refund to pay another persons FTB debt. For ease of administration, consent was limited to the debtor’s current spouse. Sec 82 of the same Act allows the Commonwealth to recover a debt from the income tax refund of a person who has given consent under sec 93. (2) In order for an income tax refund to be used to offset a spouse’s FTB debt, it is a Centrelink requirement that the Customer Reference Number (CRN) be provided to ensure the tax refund is correctly applied, where consent to use the CRN has been given. (3) and (4) Authorisation only relates to consent to use an income tax refund to pay a spouse’s FTB overpayment. The recovery of an FTB debt from the debtor’s own income tax refund is contained in sec 82 of the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Act 1999. The Legislation does not require that the Commonwealth obtain consent to use the debtor’s own income tax refund to recover their FTB debt. Foreign Affairs: Iraq (Question No. 2525) Mr Organ asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 October 2003: (1) Can he confirm the report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 26 September 2003 that a dozen Australian weapon inspectors have been in Iraq for four months. (2) Is he able to say on what date Australian weapon inspectors were deployed to Iraq.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer provided the following(3) Can he explain how the Australian jurisdiction extended to Australians serving overseas by the Crimes (Overseas) Amendment Act 2003 will apply to those Australian weapon inspectors who were deployed in Iraq before 1 July 2003. (4) Is he able to say how many Australian civilians were deployed in Iraq prior to 1 July 2003 and can he explain whether arrangements are in place, or planned, to extend Australian jurisdiction to them. (1) and (2) The first Australian Iraq Survey Group Contingent (ASISC), consisting in late October of fifteen Australian weapon inspectors, first deployed to the Middle East on 12 May 2003 and into the Iraqi theatre on 30 May 2003. The second contingent arrived in the Middle East on 2 November and deployed into the Iraqi theatre on 4 November 2003. All the members of the first ASISC contingent had returned to Australia by 14 November 2003. (3) The Crimes (Overseas) Amendment Act 2003 gives the government the power to extend Australian criminal jurisdiction to certain categories of Australians serving overseas. The Act has been drafted so that it may cover certain acts committed after 1 July 2003. The Governor General has recently approved regulations extending Australian criminal jurisdiction to Australian civilians serving in Iraq for acts committed from 1 July 2003. The legislation does not cover acts committed before 1 July 2003. In deciding to allow retrospective regulations to be made, the Government needed to be sure that Australians who were deployed to Iraq were protected by Australian criminal jurisdiction for the maximum amount of time possible. However, in the interests of fairness, the Government also wanted those Australians to be aware that criminal jurisdiction was to be extended over them. The Government issued a media release on 26 June 2003 announcing that the amendments to the Act were to be introduced and that Australian criminal jurisdiction would be applied retrospectively to 1 July 2003 to Australian civilians deployed in certain operations overseas. (4) It is difficult to determine the precise number of Australians in Iraq prior to 1 July 2003. In addition to the indeterminate time frame, Australians have been and are employed in various capacities, some of which are private and therefore not necessarily known by government. As noted in question three, the Crimes (Overseas) Amendment Act 2003 gives the Government power to extend Australian criminal jurisdiction to certain categories of Australians overseas. The legislation does not cover acts committed before 1 July 2003. Foreign Affairs: Islamic Charities (Question No. 2528) Mr Danby asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 October 2003: (1) Is he aware of the (a) International Islamic Relief Organisation (IIRO), (b) World Assembly of Muslim Youth (WAMY), and (c) The Charitable Foundations of al-Haramian. (2) Can he confirm whether the (a) IIRO, (b) WAMY, and (c) The Charitable Foundations of alHaramian, is (i) listed by the United Nations as a terrorist group or a group funding terrorist organisations; if so, is it illegal to handle assets or provide finance to this group in Australia, and (ii) listed by the United Nations as having links with al-Qaeda and/or the Taliban; if so, is this group proscribed under the Criminal Code. (3) Which countries have proscribed the (a) IIRO, (b) WAMY, and (c) The Charitable Foundations of al-Haramian. (4) Does the Government have information indicating that these organisations (a) fund terrorist organisations, (b) are terrorist organisations themselves, or (c) have links with terrorist organisations.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Howard
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(5) Can he confirm whether (a) these organisations receive donations from the Saudi royal family, (b) these organisations are headed by Saudi Cabinet Members, (c) there are documented links between IIRO and al-Qaeda going back to 1989, (d) Bin Laden’s brother-in-law, Muhammad Jamal Khalifa runs IIRO’s Philippines office, (e) Muhammad al-Zawahiri, the brother of Ayman al-Zawahiri, a senior al-Qaeda figure, is employed in IIRO’s Albanian office, (f) Kenya has proscribed the IIRO, (g) an IIRO employee was implicated in planning a terrorist attack in India, (h) there are documented links between IIRO and WAMY and Hamas, (i) Al-Haramain funds al-Qaeda operations in South East Asia, (j) Al-Haramain was the source of the US$100,000 that the Jemaah Islamiah (JI) financier, Hambali, admitted was given to JI for the families of the Bali suicide bombers, but was instead used to fund the suicide bombing of the Marriott Hotel in Jakarta, (k) AlHaramain’s offices in Bosnia, Somalia and Azerbaijan were closed down for financing terrorist organisations, and (l) Canadian authorities recently closed the offices of WAMY and arrested its local operators for alleged involvement in al-Qaeda sponsored terrorism. (6) Is the Islamic Youth Organisation in Sydney affiliated to the WAMY. (7) Is he aware of allegations made before the US Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Terrorism, Technology and Homeland Security of links between the Council of American Islamic Relations (CAIR) and the Islamic Assembly of North America (IANA) and various terrorist organisations. (8) Is he aware of any individuals or organisations in Australia who (a) have links to, (b) provide funding to, or (c) receive funding from CAIR or IANA; if so, who, and are they under investigation. (9) Is he able to say whether the (a) IIRO, (b) WAMY, and (c) The Charitable Foundations of alHaramian, is present in Australia. (10) Is he aware of any individuals or organisations in Australia who (a) have links to, (b) provide funding to, or (c) receive funding from (i) IIRO, (ii) WAMY, or (iii) al-Haramain; if so, who, and are they under investigation. (1) Yes, I am aware of these organisations. (2) Please refer to the answer provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in response to Question No.2527 (Hansard, Wednesday 26 November 2003, page 22880). (3) Please refer to the answer provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in response to Question No.2527 (Hansard, Wednesday 26 November 2003, page 22880). (4) The Government is aware of allegations about the activities of some of these organisations including that they fund terrorist organisations and have links with terrorist groups. Where there is a basis for believing the activities of such organisations are of security concern and where those organisations are within Australia’s jurisdiction they are investigated by the relevant law enforcement and security authorities. I do not propose to comment on precisely which organisations are the subject of such investigation. (5) The work required to answer the honourable member’s question would involve significant diversion of resources within the department and I am not prepared to authorise these resources. (6) I am not aware of the Islamic Youth Organisation. If the question concerns the Islamic Youth Movement in Sydney then the Government has no information to suggest it is affiliated with the World Assembly of Muslim Youth (WAMY). (7) Please refer to the answer provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in response to Question No.2527 (Hansard, Wednesday 26 November 2003, page 22880).
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(8) There are individuals and organisations in Australia who have links to various overseas based Islamic charities and businesses. While there is a basis for believing the activities of such individuals and organisations are of security concern, they are investigated by the relevant law enforcement and security authorities. I do not propose to comment on precisely which individuals and organisations are the subject of such an investigation. (9) Of the three groups referred to in the question, only the WAMY has an office in Australia. The WAMY was established in Australia in 2002. (10) As stated above, there are individuals and organisations in Australia who have links to various overseas-based Islamic charities and businesses. While there is a basis for believing the activities of such individuals and organisations are of security concern, they are investigated by the relevant law enforcement and security authorities. I do not propose to comment on precisely which individuals and organisations are the subject of such investigation. Environment: Pesticides (Question No. 2535) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 7 October 2003: (1) Are Australian rivers, lakes, and other waterways monitored to assess whether they are contaminated by pesticides; if so, (a) which agencies carry out this monitoring, (b) does the monitoring examine whether the contamination levels threaten their suitability for drinking water or for fish habitat, and (c) which waterways in Australia have been affected by pesticides or chemical contaminants. (2) Are Australian soil micro-organisms, Australian fish, Australian birds or Australian mammals tested to assess the effects of pesticide use with a view to establishing safe limits for pesticide use, similar to the work by the United States department of Agriculture and the United States Environment Protection Authority. (3) What are the run off characteristics for commonly used chemicals on various Australian soil types. (4) What are the soil absorption rates for Australian soil types for commonly used pesticides. (1)(a)State agencies, research institutions and industry bodies undertake monitoring for pesticides in water. The Commonwealth has allocated funds from 2005-06 for a more comprehensive national program of monitoring chemicals, including pesticides, in the Australian environment. (b) The National Water Quality Management Strategy 2002 (revised) Australian and New Zealand Guidelines for Fresh and Marine Water Quality provide a methodology for deriving locally applicable trigger values (which if exceeded should trigger management action) to protect the environmental values of a water body. For protection of an environmental value of aquatic ecosystem protection, ideal testing would involve collecting data on local species. However, this data is very rarely available (see answer to (2) below) and the Guidelines provide a set of default trigger values, exceedences of which should trigger investigation. (c) As the Australian Government does not keep monitoring data on pesticides, the answer to this question should be sought from State and Territory agencies. (2) There are some programs currently developing ecotoxicological test methods with Australian species (generally aquatic invertebrates and some fish), including those run by the Environmental Research Institute of the Supervising Scientist (ERISS). Work in this area indicates that Australian species generally do not differ greatly in their sensitivity to a broad range of toxicants, although
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:some unique situations may arise, for example with the extremely soft waters of tropical northern Australia, or high temperature waters. Testing on local mammals and birds is forbidden or strongly discouraged in those States which have previously carried out toxicity testing, and testing on fish has also been discouraged for animal welfare reasons. Most testing on Australian organisms has been done using aquatic crustaceans and fish. (3), (4) Specific chemical characteristics are known to the Department of the Environment and Heritage through commercial-in-confidence information provided to the Department by the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA). The Department of the Environment and Heritage assesses this information and provides the APVMA with written reports and advice regarding the potential for harmful environmental effects of pesticides (when used as directed). The Department is not able to disclose commercial-in-confidence information. However the APVMA’s website www.apvma.gov.au makes various chemical-specific reports available which can contain some of the information sought. Additionally the APVMA can make its technical reports available on request. (2) How much of the money spent through the NHT has been (a) spent on reports or studies, (b) paid to consultants, and (c) been paid to farmers. (1) To 30 June 2003, $1,543.3 million has been spent through the Natural Heritage Trust. (2) (a), (b), (c) Investments under the Trust seek wherever possible multiple, integrated outcomes. An individual proposal may include work by some or all of the following: consultants, individual landholders, farmers, local government, catchment authorities or community groups. Almost all proposals involve the production of a report of some form. It is not practicable to provide a funding breakdown by these three categories since the commencement of the Trust. Environment: Greenhouse Gas Emissions (Question No. 2553) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 7 October 2003: (1) What information does the Government have concerning the likely size of the hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica between now and December. (2) Is it likely that the hole in the ozone layer will be larger than that which occurred in 2002; if so, to what extent. (1) The Government has been monitoring the size of the Antarctic ozone hole during this spring using data from international satellites and observational networks coordinated by agencies, including the World Meteorological Organization. The hole peaked in size in September at about 28 million km2. This is about the same size reached by the hole of spring 2000. The ozone hole is now decreasing in size, also at a rate very similar to that observed in 2000. If this year’s hole continues to follow the decay path of the 2000 hole, it will gradually reduce in size to about 10 million km2 by the end of November and then rapidly decay to nothing. The speed of the decay is dependent on the strength and shape of the polar vortex; if the polar vortex subsides at a rapid rate then the Antarctic ozone hole for this spring could dissipate well before December. However, current indications are that the decay process will be very similar to that of 2000. The Government’s recently passed Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Legislation Amendment Bill will reduce the threat to the ozone layer and cut Australia’s greenhouse gas emissions by the equivalent of nearly six million tonnes of carbon dioxide, or one per cent of 1990 levels in 2010, putting Australia within striking distance of its Kyoto target. The Act sets up a framework through which the Australian Government, with input from industry, can develop the regulations controlling and managing the use of synthetic gases. Industry involvement and support will be critical to the implementation of those regulations and the establishment of a truly national approach to the control of ozone-depleting substances and their synthetic greenhouse gas replacements. The Act will also enable Australia to ratify the Beijing Amendment, the most recent amendment to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. This amendment controls a new ozone-depleting substance – bromochloromethane – and limits trade in ozone-depleting HCFCs to countries that have committed to their phase out. The new Act covers substances such as chlorofluorocarbons, hydrochlorofluorocarbons, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons, bromochloromethane, halons, and methyl bromide that are used in air conditioning, refrigeration, fumigation, foam, fire protection, precision cleaning, sterilization, laboratory and analytical research. (2) This year’s Antarctic ozone hole, at 28 million km2, was about 10 million km2 larger than the 2002 hole, but about the same size as the ozone hole observed in 2000. The size of the Antarctic hole each year depends on a number of meteorological factors, as well as on the concentration of ozonedepleting chemicals. In 2002 unusual weather patterns restricted the size of the ozone hole in comparison with those of recent years. Meteorological conditions this year were much closer to average and hence more conducive to the formation of a larger ozone hole than in 2002.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Terrorism: Capital Punishment (Question No. 2566) Mr Murphy asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 8 October 2003: (1) Is he aware of the remarks of His Honour Justice Michael Kirby who drew attention to his view on the death penalty during his address in Melbourne to mark the Centenary of the High Court of Australia and, in particular, is he aware of Justice Kirby’s statement that imposing the death penalty is the ultimate acknowledgment of the failure of civilisation. (2) What was his response to the poll conducted in August 2003 in which 56 percent of the respondents replied that they were in favour of the death penalty for those found guilty of committing major acts of terrorism. (3) Can he confirm that he is opposed to the death penalty for all crimes and that he will campaign against those who promote the re-introduction of capital punishment. (1) I have seen media reports on Justice Kirby’s comments. (2) There has been, and will continue to be, a variety of views within the Australian community on the issue of whether the death penalty should be reintroduced. (3) I have said publicly that I do not support the death penalty in Australia. I have also said that I will not stand in the way of public debate on the issue. Health: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (Question No. 2568) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 8 October 2003: (1) Is there evidence of irresponsible or wasteful use of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS); if so; what is the evidence. (2) What is the cost to taxpayers of the Government’s (a) electronic media, (b) print media, and (c) pamphlet campaign titled Here’s the prescription for a healthy Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme featuring Dr James Wright. (3) What is the amount of the fees paid to Dr James Wright for this advertising campaign. (4) How will the effectiveness of this advertising campaign be measured. (5) When will details of this evaluation be made available to the public. (1) Evidence of consumers stockpiling PBS prescription medicines has been found in research commissioned by the Department in February 2002 and in November 2002, and by the Health Insurance Commission in May 2003. The February 2002 research found that more than half the people surveyed believed that some people received PBS subsidised prescriptions they did not really need. A similar number thought that people should ask their doctor if they could do without medication by perhaps changing their lifestyle. The November 2002 research found that many people stocked up on prescription medicines for convenience but did not always use them. People also admitted that they often went to their doctor expecting to receive a prescription, which they then filled just in case it was required. This kind of behaviour, while inadvertent, does constitute waste. The Department’s research was supported by specific research into stockpiling of medicines, which was commissioned by the Health Insurance Commission in May 2003. This study found that 25 per
title: Questions On Notice

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:cent of people believed that stockpiling was an acceptable form of behaviour and that they had little awareness of the consequences of this to the overall cost of the PBS. The research findings are supported by anecdotal evidence. Pharmacists conducting Home Medicines Reviews indicate that stockpiling is a significant issue. Ministerial correspondence also indicates that stockpiling occurs. (2) (a) Electronic media -: television media buy $8,364,484.00 (GST inclusive); Non-English Speaking Background radio media buy $124,940.17 (GST inclusive); Indigenous radio media buy $149,109.54 (GST inclusive). (b) Print media -: Non English Speaking Background press media buy $148,445.15 (GST inclusive); Indigenous press media buy $42,906.53 (GST inclusive). (c) In relation to the cost of the campaign booklet entitled Here’s the prescription for a healthy PBS, the cost of design was $24,970 (GST inclusive) and the cost of printing 1,400,000 copies $326,356.80 (GST inclusive). (3) Dr James Wright was paid $80,000 for appearing in the television commercials and on supporting campaign information materials. This fee is within range for a presenter with Dr Wright’s media profile. (4) Benchmark and tracking research will measure the effectiveness of the campaign. (5) A decision will be made on the public availability of evaluations commissioned for the campaign once they have been completed. Throsby Electorate: Baby Bonus (Question No. 2572) Ms George asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 October 2003: (1) How many people in the electoral division of Throsby received a (a) Baby Bonus payment of any amount in 2002-2003, (b) Baby Bonus payment of $2,500 in 2002-2003 and (c) Baby Bonus payment of $500 in 2002-2003. (2) How many people in the electoral division on Throsby have applied for a Baby Bonus payment in 2002-2003 and been rejected. Where a claimant’s taxable income is $25,000 or less they will be entitled to $500 (although this amount is reduced where the claimant did not have legal responsibility for and care of the child for the whole year). International Labour Organisation: Child Labour (Question No. 2577 to 2579) Mr Kerr asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 9 October 2003: (1) Does any Australian statistical office, department or agency have responsibility for gathering information on child labour in Australia and, in particular, the worse forms of child labour. (2) What arrangements exist to ensure cooperation between Australian law enforcement agencies and those of other countries with respect to the identification, arrest and prosecution of offenders involved in child prostitution, use of children for pornography and child sex tourism.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) What assistance targeted at the elimination of the worse forms of child labour is Australia providing to other countries. (4) Does Australia have a national program of action to eliminate the worse forms of child labour. the honourable member’s question: (1) There is no Commonwealth office, department or agency with specific responsibility for gathering statistics on child labour in Australia. Detailed information is provided to the Commonwealth Department of Employment and Workplace Relations by the States and Territories for Australia’s annual reports to the International Labour Organization on child labour. (2) The Australian Federal Police (AFP) has developed an International Liaison Officer Network based in a number of Asian countries, which contributes significantly to ongoing investigations aimed at combating child sex tourism and related offences. The AFP monitors travel movements of paedophiles in and out of Australia through Customs, the AFP International Liaison Officer Network and Interpol, and advises host countries so they can take investigative action in the first instance. The newly established AFP Transnational Sexual Exploitation and Trafficking Team has recently been made responsible for child sex tourism matters and is responsible for the collection of intelligence and facilitates both domestic and offshore investigations into child sex tourism. Australia has signed memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with a number of Asian and Pacific countries. The MOUs provide the framework for close cooperation between the AFP and other law enforcement agencies in the region. They facilitate greater exchange of information on child sexual abuse that may assist in identifying groups and individuals involved in the sexual exploitation of children. Australia generally seeks to assist the home country in prosecution action in the first instance, but where appropriate our child sex tourism offences (contained in Part IIIA of the Crimes Act 1914) are rigorously enforced. As at 1 December 2003, in Australia 16 persons have been charged and 12 persons convicted, with one matter ongoing, under Australia’s child sex tourism offences. These offenders have largely been apprehended on return to Australia or, in isolated cases, extradited to Australia to face prosecution in Australian courts. Nineteen Australians have been arrested and charged overseas, with eight of those persons having been convicted in the jurisdiction in which they offended. A further eight of these matters are ongoing. The Australian High Tech Crime Centre (AHTCC) conducts investigations and coordinates information about online child exploitation matters, including the distribution of child pornography. The AHTCC has established and continues to enhance relationships with international law enforcement agencies bilaterally, multilaterally, via Interpol channels and through the AFP’s International Liaison Officer Network. In addition, the AHTCC has formed relationships with non-government and private sector agencies whose endeavours regularly uncover online child exploitation matters. Through these relationships the AHTCC regularly receives and disseminates information about online child exploitation to other law enforcement agencies. The AHTCC is currently formulating a strategic international relationships policy which will formalise the arrangements with its international partners. (3) The Australian aid program addresses the fundamental causes of child labour and related forms of exploitation of women and children in developing countries. Support for improved governance, in particular strengthening law and justice, human rights, democratic institutions and developing civil society, also contributes to an environment where child labour and other forms of exploitation are less likely to occur. In addition, Australia continues to provide annual core funding for multilateral agencies such as UNICEF and substantially contributes to human rights organisations for their continued promotion and protection of human rights, including those of children. Australia has held talks and workshops with a number of developing countries addressing human rights issues,
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer toincluding specific discussions on children’s rights and child labour. Australia also supports a range of bilateral country programs and non-government organisations that focus on local level prevention and support for women and children vulnerable to exploitation, targeted at, amongst other things, the victims or potential victims of child sex tourism and the trafficking of persons. (4) In response to the outcomes document, A World Fit for Children, arising from the special session of the United Nations General Assembly on children in May 2002, the Australian Government is developing a national plan of action based on the commitments within this document. Among the range of issues to be addressed by the national plan is the elimination of the worse forms of child labour. Australia signed the Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child on the Sale of Children, Child Prostitution and Child Pornography in New York on 18 December 2001. With a view to ratification, the Attorney-General has written to State and Territory Attorneys-General, seeking advice on whether their laws comply with the Optional Protocol and requesting that the issue be put on the next Standing Committee of Attorneys-General meeting agenda. The Australian Government also strongly supports ratifying the International Labour Organization Convention 182 Concerning the Prohibition and Immediate Action for the Elimination of the Worst Forms of Child Labour. The Government is working closely with the States and Territories encouraging them to enact legislation that fully complies with the Convention’s requirements, paving the way for ratification. Employment: Assistance Programs (Question No. 2592) Mr Albanese asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 13 October 2003: (1) Would he provide a breakdown by Employment Service areas of the number of jobseekers expected to enter the Job Network in (a) 2003-2004, (b) 2004-2005, and (c) 2005-2006, distinguishing between eligible Job Network jobseekers and Job Search Support jobseekers. (2) Would he also provide details by Employment Service areas of the number of jobseekers that his Department anticipates will enter (a) Intensive Assistance–Job Search Training, (b) Intensive Assistance-Customised Assistance (first period), and (c) Intensive Assistance-Customised Assistance (second period) in (i) 2003-2004, (b) 2004-2005, and (c) 2005-2006. The department does not estimate the number of job seekers to enter Job Network and the various Job Network services at the Employment Service Area (ESA) level by year. Local labour market conditions vary substantially. However, to assist Job Network members to understand the new Employment Services Contract3 servicing arrangements, a range of data based on historical numbers of job seekers and average operating year information at the ESA level was released on the internet and can be located at www.workplace.gov.au/esc3tender. Housing: Downturn (Question No. 2605) Mr Latham asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 October 2003: What assessment has the Government made on the possible impact of a housing downturn on nondeposit-taking financial institutions and associated mortgage insurers and what does this assessment show?
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:According to the Reserve Bank of Australia, the financial sector, including non-deposit taking financial institutions, is well-placed to withstand a downturn in the housing sector. Factors contributing to this assessment include: the relatively strong position of borrowers, with around two-thirds of mortgagees being ahead of their repayment schedule; robust loan-to-valuation ratios, averaging at 65-70 per cent on new housing loans; access to mortgage insurance from sound, prudentially regulated insurers; and the use of residential mortgage-backed securities to distribute credit risk over a wide investor base, rather than the balance sheets of financial institutions. The associated lenders mortgage insurers are also well-placed to withstand a housing downturn. To qualify for the concessional risk weighting applied to housing loans for capital adequacy purposes (under APRA’s prudential standards), mortgages from authorised deposit-taking institutions which have a loan-to-valuation ratio above 80 per cent must be covered by mortgage insurance from an insurer at least A-rated. In determining credit ratings, ratings agencies require mortgage insurers to hold capital sufficient to cover a number of ‘worse-case scenarios’, including a prolonged downturn in the economy and substantial falls in house prices. APRA supervises lenders mortgage insurers and has been monitoring their resilience to potential adverse movements in the housing market. This involves assessment of claim files, reserving, reinsurance arrangements and overall capital strength. Further information can be obtained from the Reserve Bank of Australia’s Annual Report for 2003. Immigration: Unregistered Agents (Question No. 2606) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 15 October 2003: (1) Did he announce on 25 September 2002 that the Government would be acting upon all the recommendations of the 2001-2002 Review of Statutory Self-Regulation of the Migration Advice Industry, otherwise known as the Spicer Report. (2) What action, if any, has the Government taken to implement recommendation 25 of the report to ensure faster and more effective investigation and prosecution of unregistered agents and agents involved in fraud. (3) What specific action has his department taken to (a) attach higher priority to investigations of unregistered practice, (b) build stronger relationships with the Director of Public Prosecutions to facilitate prosecution and the finalisation of cases, (c) revise its guidelines to staff on referring to investigation units cases of suspected unregistered practice or fraud to improve the quality of information referred and the speed of referral, and (d) undertake wider publicity of prosecutions of unregistered practice. (1) Yes. (2) The Government has taken action to implement Recommendation 25 of the Review. This has included the establishment of a Migration Agents Taskforce within my Department in June 2003. This taskforce, has been set up to target the activities of agents, both registered and unregistered, suspected of being involved in organised malpractice and fraud. It has as its key outcomes, the disruption or cessation of these activities through both administrative and judicial sanctions where appropriate. Furthermore, the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents Integrity Measures) Bill 2003, which is currently before Parliament, contains provisions that will protect consumers and
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Hardgrave
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:assist in the successful prosecution of offenders. A key element is a provision that will ensure that civil proceedings cannot be taken against persons who provide information to my Department about the activities of agents. This should encourage clients to complain and testify against those that have exploited them and should lead to an increase in the number of successful actions taken against unregistered agents. (3) (a) Allegations of unregistered practice are given a high priority by my Department. The establishment of the Migration Agents Taskforce has further increased the focus, priority and capacity to investigate unregistered agents and registered agents involved in immigration fraud, or other criminal activities. (b) My Department already has a close working relationship with the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions and this relationship is being strengthened through the work of the Migration Agents Taskforce. The Taskforce is also working closely with the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Tax Office, Centrelink and the Migration Agents Registration Authority (MARA) in the collection of evidence and the application of the appropriate sanctions. Coordinated operations with other agencies are a priority in addressing the multi-faceted activity of some of the worse agents. (c) My Department issued a revised Administrative Circular; “Instructions for DIMIA Employees on Making Complaints about Registered Migration Agents and Unregistered Persons Operating as Agents” (AC 1068) on 27 May 2003. The revised circular assists the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) staff to refer information about conduct of concern by a registered agent, or the activities of an unregistered agent, efficiently and effectively. My department’s guidelines regarding fraud information management, “DIMIA Fraud Investigation” (AC 1008) are also progressively being revised and implemented. (d) My Department has taken several steps to increase public awareness about unregistered practice. Improved information about unregistered practice is now available to consumers via my Department’s re-developed web site. This includes more detailed information concerning the referral of information about unregistered agents to the Department, so that such allegations can be investigated. The recently established Migration Agents Taskforce is expected to produce a number of significant prosecutions of unregistered agents. Its focus is on unregistered agents and registered agents involved in immigration fraud, or other criminal activities. Once such prosecutions are finalised, I intend to capitalise on media interest in migration agent issues to further increase public awareness about unregistered practice and the need to use a registered agent. Legal Aid: Funding (Question No. 2609) (1) Is he aware of his predecessor’s statement on 15 December 1999 that “there is evidence that some experienced private lawyers are unwilling to take on legal aid cases”. (2) What steps has he taken to inform himself of the extent to which private lawyers have withdrawn from performing legal aid work under the current legal aid funding agreements.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Attorney
theText: General, upon notice, on 15 October 2003:(3) For each State and Territory, how many private practitioners have performed legal aid work under the current legal aid funding agreements. (4) Is he or his department aware of any research, reports or submissions which address this issue; if so, what are the details. (5) What steps has he taken or will he take to arrest the decline in the number of private lawyers undertaking legal aid work. (1) I am aware of my predecessor’s statement. (2) The Attorney-General’s Department has briefed me on the issue of private practitioners withdrawing from legal aid work. The Department has also commissioned a report on the participation of legal practitioners in the legal aid market from the Centre for Labour Market Research at the University of Canberra. (3) The Attorney-General’s Department does not collect data on the number of individual solicitors engaged by legal aid commissions. (4) The Attorney-General’s Department is aware of a number of research papers, reports and submissions which refer to this issue, including a number of submissions to the current Senate Inquiry into Legal Aid and Access to Justice. It would not be practical for my Department to provide details of all such material to which it has had access. However, the following may be of assistance. Dewar, Giddings, J. & Parker, S. (1998) The Impact of Changes in Legal Aid on Criminal and Family Law Practice in Queensland: A Research Report commissioned by the Queensland Law Society and The Family Law Practitioners’ Association, Faculty of Law, Griffith University. Australian Law Reform Commission (2000) Report No 89 Managing Justice: A review of the federal civil justice system, Australian Government Printing Service, Canberra. Hunter, R (1999) Family Law Case Profiles, Law Foundation of NSW for the Justice Research Centre, Sydney. Hunter, R, Genovese, A, Chrzanowski, A & Melville, A (2000) Legal Services in Family Law, Law Foundation of New South Wales, Sydney. Law Council of Australia (LCA) (2001) 2010: A Discussion Paper: Challenges for the Legal Profession. National Legal Aid (September 2002), Survey of Stage of Matter Funding Model, Family Law Fee. (5) I will be considering this issue in the context of negotiations with the States and Territories and legal aid commissions for new legal aid agreements to replace the current agreements which are due to expire on 30 June 2004. Trade: Live Animal Exports (Question No. 2612) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 15 October 2003: (1) Has he seen the report by Rosslyn Beeby titled “NFF calls for live export inquiry” in The Canberra Times on 27 September 2003. (2) How many sheep have already died on the current voyage of the MV Cormo Express. (3) What is the highest number of livestock deaths on an Australian live export voyage.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(4) How many sheep die each year on ships involved in the Australian live export trade. (5) Will he support an inquiry examining all aspects of the live export trade; if so, when will it be established; if not, why not. (1) Yes. (2) At the completion of the voyage there were 5,691 mortalities. (3) The Department has livestock mortality records back to 2000 and since this time the highest number of livestock mortalities on an Australian live export voyage is 6,119 sheep in July 2002. (4) Year Mortality No. Mortality (%) 2000 61,000 1.31 2001 78,749 1.26 2002 75,530 1.24 2003 (end Sept) 27,372 0.79. (5) On 10 October, I announced Dr John Keniry would chair a broad ranging investigation into Australia’s livestock export industry. Dr Keniry has been supported by a panel that has considerable expertise and experience at the highest level in the livestock industry. The review team will report to me soon. Howard Government: Advertising (Question No. 2614 to 2631) Mr Murphy asked all portfolio ministers, upon notice, on 15 October 2003: (1) How much money was spent on Government advertising by the Minister’s department and agencies in the Minister’s portfolio, in the financial years ended 30 June (a) 1997; (b) 1998; (c) 1999; (d) 2000; (e) 2001; (f) 2002; and (g) 2003. Expenditure has been allocated as accurately as possible against current portfolios where Administrative Arrangements Order changes have occurred over the period. (2) The attached table reflects campaign advertising expenditure by portfolio for the months of July, August and September 2003 and a whole-of-government figure for non-campaign advertising for the period.
