theText: The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to(c) PMC is not collected at airports. Airlines collect PMC as part of the airline ticket price and remit to Customs under formal Arrangements. It is not possible to attribute money collected to individual airports. (2) No. (3) Outward immigration processing is one of a number of passenger processing activities conducted within a single cost centre for passenger processing at airports. Costs are not reduced to the level specified in the question. The total Customs expenditure for airport processing activities during the last financial year was $M158.3. Immigration: Former Child Migrants (Question No. 2739) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 6 November 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2262 (Hansard, 3 November 2003, page 21804), is he correctly quoted in the Sunday Telegraph of 2 November 2003 as stating that the Travel Fund for Former Child migrants ‘has run out of money’ and ‘had been so popular that its three-year allocation of $3 million had been used up in the first year of operation’; if so, how are these statements consistent with his answer to the House on the same matter. (2) What is the total amount that has been spent by the Fund to date. (3) What is the estimated value of applications that have been approved for which travel has not yet occurred. (4) What is the estimated size of the former child migrant population and what proportion of former child migrants is likely to benefit from the Travel Fund under current arrangements. (5) In respect to the erection of memorials in each State, what arrangements, if any, exist for consultation with groups representing former child migrants in relation to the location and design memorials. (1) My press release of 4 November made it clear that I reject claims the Travel Fund has run out of money. The Australian Government is currently meeting all eligible requests for travel from those who have not previously received assistance. (2) Expenses incurred in relation to the Travel Fund from its commencement to 31 October 2003 were $1,570,775. (3) As at 31 October 2003 there were 209 approved applicants who had not yet travelled. If all approved applicants proceed to travel (less than 86% of approved applicants proceeded to travel under the UK Fund), the estimated value of approved applications for which travel has not yet occurred is $1,382,117. (4) The exact numbers of former child migrants sent to Australia is not known. The Australian Senate Community Affairs References Committee report Lost Innocents: Righting the Record (2001), estimates (p.69 of the Report) that 6,000 to 7,500 child migrants were sent to Australia in the course of the 20th Century, with 3,000 to 3,500 being sent post World War II. The number of approved applications to 31 October 2003 is 406. (5) The nature of consultation in relation to creation of memorials is a matter for each State government. States have provided the following advice:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Hardgrave
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:New South Wales The NSW Department of Community Services, in consultation with International Social Service (ISS), surveyed a number of former child migrants applying to the Australian Travel Fund regarding the form and location of a NSW memorial. Consultation is continuing. Victoria The Victorian Department of Human Services, on advice from the Child Migrant Trust in December 2002, is working with the International Association of Former Child Migrants and their families. Their representative has been involved in all discussions. Queensland The Queensland Department of Families undertook a consultation process, which included: contacting as many former child migrants placed in Queensland as possible; ascertaining the level of interest of former child migrants in the establishment of a memorial; ascertaining the views of former child migrants on the establishment of a joint memorial at Neerkol to commemorate former child migrants and former residents; and inviting the participation of former child migrants in a consultation process to establish a memorial. Western Australia The Western Australian Department for Community Development has undertaken the following consultation: Talk back radio both metro and regional radio; Advertisements in the West Australian Newspaper and the Local Community Newspapers; and Two fora were held – invitations to attend were extended to all former child migrants, all agencies who currently work with child migrants, all former receiving agency groups and all child migrant social groups. Discussions are being held between former child migrants, Fremantle City Council and the artists involved. South Australia The South Australian Department of Human Services has undertaken the following consultation on the memorial project: The terms and conditions for the funding have been discussed with a group of former child migrants active in the development of this project, and the support of the Catholic Church in Adelaide is being sought. Letters and advertisements in the newspaper will be used to contact, and seek the views, of those former child migrants not already known to the Department, or to the current active group. Tasmania The Tasmanian Department of Health and Human Services will soon advertise across the state, seeking nominations from former child migrants who are interested in participating in a consultative group tasked with developing a plan for the establishment of the memorial. Commonwealth Government: Consultancies (Question No. 2741 to 2758) Mr Murphy asked all portfolio ministers, upon notice, on 6 November 2003: (1) Has the Minister seen the report by Alan Ramsey titled “The taxpayer’s bill where bill is short for billion” in the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 November 2003 which stated that last financial year consultancies let by Commonwealth departments and agencies was over $500 million, up from $313 million a year earlier. (2) How much money was spent on consultancies by the Minister’s department and agencies in the Minister’s portfolios in the financial years ended 30 June (a) 1997; (b) 1998; (c) 1999; (d) 2000; (e) 2001; (f) 2002, and (g) 2003. (3) How much money has been spent on consultancies by the Minister’s department and agencies in the Minister’s portfolio since 1 July 2003. swer to the honourable member’s questions: I am replying on behalf of all portfolio Ministers. (1) &(2) Expenditure on consultancies over $10,000 is reported in each agency’s annual report. Details of contracts, including consultancies, worth more than $2,000 are published in the Gazette within 6 weeks. It would be a significant task for agencies to aggregate the expenditure on consultancies valued at more than $2,000 but less than $10,000 over the last 7 years and the Government is not prepared to divert resources to that task. (3) As noted in the answer to part 2, details of consultancies worth more than $2,000 are published in the Gazette. Family and Community Services: Child Support Payments (Question No. 2760) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 6 November 2003: (1) Can he explain the jurisprudential basis for the assignment of responsibility for the registration and collection of child support payments to the Australian Taxation Office. (2) Is he aware that people owing a child support debt to the Commonwealth are being assessed and required to make payments in excess of the reasonable living expenses of a child. (3) What are the relevant provisions of the law with respect to the calculation of child support payments and what is the moral and legal basis on which calculations are made. (4) Is he able to explain the relationship between the calculable amount of child support debt and the estimated reasonable expenses of raising a child. (5) What is the procedure or remedy available to an individual liable for a child support debt calculated according to the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 and the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 which is greater than the reasonable expenses of raising a child. (6) Can he explain the legal philosophy underpinning the requirement for an individual liable for child support payments being compelled under threat of punishment to make payments where the assessed amount of child support exceeds the reasonable expenses of raising the child or children. (7) Is he able to explain the moral and policy basis for the existence of a system in which the child support debt calculated may be in excess of a child’s needs. (8) What action is being taken to moderate the amounts of debt owed which are in excess of a child’s needs. (1) In October 1998, the Child Support Agency (CSA) moved from the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) to the Department of Family and Community Services (FaCS), following the creation of FaCS under the new Administrative Arrangement Orders. Responsibility for the general administration of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 now lies with the Secretary (of FaCS) pursuant to Section 11 of the Act.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following an
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) and (4) The current system of Child Support formula assessments was established by the Parliament in order to determine what levels of support should be provided for children by separated parents. The child support formula is not based directly on the costs of children, rather it is intended to ensure that parents share in the costs of supporting their children according to their capacity. The formula takes account of the number of children, the level of care provided by each parent, the self-support requirements of both parents and the income of parents as it changes over time. While the child support formula is not based directly on the costs of children, research on costs of children was examined when the formula percentages were designed in 1988. After a review of the Child Support Scheme in 1994, the Joint Select Committee (JSC) recommended the then Department of Social Security (DSS) undertake new costs of children research. The Department Commissioned the Social Policy Research Centre (SPRC) to undertake costs of children research as part of a broader ‘budget standards’ project. Additionally, the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling (NATSEM) was chosen to supplement the SPRC research by using different methodology. When considering the estimated average direct costs of children, both reports showed that nonresident parents with high incomes were paying more than the measured costs of children in high income families. However, at other income levels this was not the case. The Government put forward a proposal to reduce the child support liability cap as part of a package of measures reforming the Child Support Scheme. However, the proposal was rejected in the Senate in June 2001. (3) The Child Support Scheme (CSS) was introduced with the bi-partisan support of Parliament to address serious concerns about child and lone parent poverty.Private parental responsibility for the financial well-being of children, even when families have separated, rather than reliance on Government funded programs, is the underlying philosophy of the Scheme. The objectives of the Scheme were amended by the Government in 1997. They are: Parents share in the cost of supporting their children according to their capacity; Adequate support is available to all children not living with both parents; Commonwealth involvement and expenditure is limited to the minimum necessary for ensuring children’s needs are met; Work incentives for both parents to participate in the labour force are not impaired; and The overall arrangements are non intrusive to personal privacy and are simple, flexible and efficient. The legislative framework for the operation of the Child Support Scheme is contained in the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988, and the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989. The child support legislation provides for administrative assessment of child support payable (the formula). (5) The Government believes that the current system of formula assessment is the appropriate method for calculating child support obligations in most cases. However, it was recognised that using formula assessments may not result in an appropriate amount of child support in every case. The Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 allows parents who disagree with an assessment to apply to the CSA for a change of assessment where 10 special circumstances exist. Additionally, parents have the option of seeking an assessment from a court with family law jurisdiction if they believe the CSA assessment is unfair. (6) Legislation determines the basis on which child support liabilities are calculated. Where child support responsibilities calculated in accordance with the legislation are avoided, the child support legislation gives the CSA extensive administrative powers to enforce child support payments. These powers include the ability to intercept taxation refunds, deduct payments from salary, wages, and Centrelink benefits, perform searches of declarations of employment made to the ATO and garnishee amounts from bank accounts. (7) This question has been addressed in the answer to Question2 above. (8) This question has been partly addressed in the answer to Question2 above. In addition, the Government is currently awaiting the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community affairs Inquiry into child Custody Arrangements in the Event of Family Separation. The terms of reference include the child support formula. Lowe Electorate: Bulk-Billing (Question No. 2768) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 24 November 2003: (1) What proportion of general practitioners (GPs) offer bulk-billing in the electoral division of Lowe. (2) What proportion of GPs offered bulk billing in the electoral division of Lowe in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, and (g) 2002. (3) Will he grant doctors who have not undergone GP training, but who have four year post-graduate experience in (a) paediatrics, (b) geriatrics, (c) general medicine, and (d) emergency medicine in the hospital system, limited access to a provider number in order to increase the supply of GPs; if so, when; if not, why not. (1) In 2002-03, 96.5% of general practitioners had at least one bulk billed service processed by the Health Insurance Commission for services rendered in the electoral division of Lowe. (2) The percentage of general practitioners who had at least one bulk billed service processed by the Health Insurance Commission for services rendered in the electoral division of Lowe in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, and (g) 2002, was as follows: 1995-96 85.7% 1996-97 85.9% 1997-98 89.0% 1998-99 90.7% 1999-00 92.0% 2000-01 90.9% 2001-02 92.0% (3) (a), (b), (c) & (d) Section 19AA of the Health Insurance Act 1973 generally requires doctors who are citizens or permanent residents of Australia to have obtained postgraduate (Fellowship) qualifications before they are able to access Medicare benefits. This is important in ensuring that the long-term medical workforce is of a high quality. There are exemptions from this general requirement for some approved training and workforce programs. The exemptions for training programs allow doctors to receive access to Medicare benefits while undertaking vocational training to receive Fellowship from the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners or one of the specialist medical colleges. The exemptions for
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:workforce programs have been focussed on areas of significant workforce shortages, such as rural areas (the Rural Locum Relief Program) or after hours work (the Approved Medical Deputising Services Program). Doctors working in the areas concerned must have achieved medical registration but need not have Fellowship. Notes to Answers (1) and (2) These statistics relate to general practitioner providers of services on a ‘fee-for-service’ basis and for which Medicare benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the year in question. In general terms, practitioners with at least 50% of Schedule fee income from non-referred (GP) attendances in the June quarter of the year in question were considered to be general practitioners. These statistics were compiled from Medicare data by servicing provider postcode. In compiling statistics for the electoral division of Lowe, since some postcodes overlap Federal electoral division boundaries, statistics by servicing provider postcode were mapped to electorate using data from the Census of Population and Housing showing the proportion of the population of each postcode in each Federal electoral division. Defence Imagery and Geospatial Organisation (Question No. 2771) Mr Gibbons asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 November 2003: (1) Is the Minister aware that at the Defence Imagery and Geospatial Organisation at Fortuna, Bendigo there is currently underway (a) a Hard Print Copy Review to review the current hard copy map printing capability of the organisation, and (b) an internal organisational review on the most suitable structure and location of the organisation. (2) Can he confirm that the internal organisation review is considering three options: (a) no movement of facilities, (b) relocation of some of the functions to Canberra, and (c) relocation of the entire facility to Canberra. (3) Is the Minister aware of the impact the loss of 150 jobs from this facility would have on the economy of the Bendigo region. (4) When will a final decision be made. able member’s question as follows: (1) Yes. (2) The review will examine a number of options for improving the effectiveness and efficiency of the business at the Fortuna complex. (3) It is premature to speculate about the future of the Defence capability at Bendigo. (4) The results of the review will be submitted to the Government for consideration in due course. Employment: Job Network (Question No. 2772) Mr Gibbons asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, 24 November 2003: (1) Can he confirm that Job Network providers are claiming funding each year for placing the same itinerant workers in the same annual seasonal employment.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honour(2) Can he explain how Job Network providers may claim funding under the pretext that they secured employment for the itinerant worker when the seasonal work is offered directly to the worker. (1) Job Network members claim funding for services delivered to job seekers in accordance with the terms and conditions contained in the Employment Services Contract (ESC) 2003-2006. Job Network members are to assist unemployed job seekers into the widest possible range of job opportunities. If a job seeker is unemployed and receives Newstart Allowance, including meeting ongoing tests for active job search for all suitable available work, the Job Network member would be eligible for an Outcome Fee if the person secured employment in a seasonal job that met normal conditions as to duration and number of hours worked. However, they do not receive an outcome for placing a job seeker into a vacancy similar to one previously held with that employer. The payment schedule for ESC services details rules limiting payment for certain repeat placements. A copy of the ESC3 contract providing full details of the services required of Job Network members and of conditions under which fees are payable is available at the www.workplace.gov.au web site – Job Network link. (2) Job Placement fees that relate to vacancy gathering, matching and placement of job seekers into vacancies are not payable where work is offered direct to the job seeker. There are no perplacement fees under the Harvest Labour Services (HLS) and National Harvest Labour Information Services (NHLIS) contracted by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations. Job Placement and HLS/NHLIS information is available at the www.workplace.gov.au web site – Job Network link. Defence: Personnel (Question No. 2777) Ms Hoare asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 November 2003: (1) For each year from 1996 to 2002, how many personnel were recruited to the Australian Defence Force (ADF) for each service and for regular forces and each category of Reserves. (2) For each year from 1996 to 2002, how many personnel left the ADF for each service and for regular forces and each category of Reserves. (3) For each year from 1996 to 2002, how many personnel left the ADF after (a) 1 month (b) 2 months (c) 6 months (d) 1 year (e) 3 years, and (d) 6 years. (4) For each year from 1996 to 2002, how many personnel were discharged from the ADF as result of (a) physical injury or illness, (b) psychological illness, (c) disciplinary reasons, and (d) administrative reasons. (5) For each year from 1996 to 2002, how many serving ADF personnel have died and, in respect of each death (a) what was the cause, and (b) what was the individual’s length of service at the time of death. (6) In respect of the ADF personnel recruited during the period from 1996 to 2002 and who have since been discharged, what was their average length of service. (7) What corrective action will the Government take in response to the rising rates of unacceptable behaviour in the ADF, in particular the Navy, revealed in the Department of Defence Report for 2002-2003.

Senior High School Safe School Environment International Labour Organisation: Child Labour Convention (Question No. 2782) Mr Melham asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 24 November 2003: (1) On what dates did the Howard Government refer ILO Convention 182, eliminating the worse forms of child labour, to each of the States and Territories. (2) Which States and Territories will require amendment of legislation prior to ratification of the Convention. (1) On 27 September 1999 the former Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business wrote to all State and Territory governments requesting their views on ratification of ILO Convention 182. On 16 May 2001 the former Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Small Business, Mr Abbott, wrote to the State and Territory Ministers responsible for workplace relations matters formally requesting that they agree to ratification of the Convention and take appropriate action to ensure compliance. Mr Abbott raised Convention 182 at a meeting of the Workplace Relations Ministers’ Council (WRMC) held on 8 November 2002. The Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers all expressed their support for ratification of the Convention and agreed to provide their governments’ formal agreement to ratification and commitment to achieve compliance where appropriate. At the WRMC meeting on 28 March 2003, Ministers renewed their commitments to ratify Convention 182 and agreed to do whatever they could to fast-track this process. A report on the latest developments was provided to the WRMC meeting held on 20 November 2003. (2) Victoria, Tasmania, the Northern Territory, and the Australian Capital Territory. AusAID Logo (Question No. 2785) Ms Plibersek asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 November: (1) How much did the change from the AusAID logo to the new logo with the Commonwealth Crest cost. (2) How much did the original change of logo from AIDAB to AusAID cost. (1) The estimated cost for the change from the AusAID logo to the new logo with the Commonwealth Crest is $25,000. (2) The change of logo from AIDAB to AusAID was completed in 1995 and the costs cannot be established without expending significant resources in investigation into archived financial records and searches through archived files. Foreign Affairs: Israel (Question No. 2791) Mrs Irwin asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 November 2003: (1) In which city is the Australian Embassy in Israel located. (2) Which city does the Australian Government recognise as the capital of Israel. (3) What official recognition does the Australian Government give to Jerusalem. (1) Tel Aviv (2) Australia does not have a view on which city is the capital of Israel. Australia does not, however, recognise Jerusalem as Israel’s capital. (3) Australia recognises Israel’s 4 June 1967 borders, including what is often referred to as West Jerusalem. Environment: Coxens Double-Eyed Fig Parrot (Question No. 2792) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 25 November 2003: (1) Has he received information concerning the sighting of the Coxens Double-eyed Fig Parrot on the Burnett River, Queensland.

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows :(2) What action has the Government taken to investigate these claims and, if its presence is found to be substantiated, to protect this species. (1) Yes. (2) The Government is liaising with the Burnett Water Pty Ltd on proposed surveys that will be conducted in the area for the sub-species during 2004. If the sighting is substantiated the Government will consider what further action is required to protect the sub-species. United States Air Force: Combat Pilots (Question No. 2800) Mr Bevis asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 November 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question 2270 (Hansard 13 October 2003, page 21285), what steps has the Minister taken to verify and ensure that United States Air force, Navy and Marine pilots operating ADF aircraft are not using amphetamines. (2) What action has the Minister taken to ensure the United States Air force, Navy and Marine pilots operating US military aircraft in Australia are not using amphetamines. (1) All ADF pilots including United States Air Force, Navy and Marine pilots operating ADF aircraft are briefed that they can only take medications approved by the ADF as being safe to use when flying. ADF medical officers are aware that amphetamines are not listed in the approved list of drugs so are not prescribed to pilots to use while flying. (2) None. United States Air Force, Navy and Marine pilots flying United States missions within Australia follow their own operational policy and the ADF does not have any jurisdiction over the control of their missions. However, it is unlikely that US pilots flying missions within Australia would require or use such medication. Customs: Duty-Free Allowance (Question No. 2801) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, upon notice, on 27 November 2003: (1) Did he announce changes to customs duty arrangements on 18 September 2003; if so, what were the details. (2) What is the Government’s estimate of the cost of the proposal and on what basis was the costing determined. (3) Have the measures been implemented; if not why not. (4) Did the Government commit to having the measures implemented before the Rugby World Cup. (1) Proposed changes to Australia’s duty free concessions were announced jointly by myself and the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator the Hon Chris Ellison on 18 September 2003. The proposed changes are: An increase in the alcohol concession from 1.125 litres to 2.25 litres. An increase in the general concession from $400 to $900 for adult travellers and from $200 to $450 for minors.

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:The abolition of the $50 waiver provision for all passengers, to be replaced with a requirement that duty and/or tax be payable on the full value of goods within any category where the concession limit for that category is exceeded. To coincide with the abolition of the waiver provision, an allowance will be made within the tobacco concession to permit the carriage of one carton (being the current concession) and one opened packet (maximum 25 sticks) without the requirement for duty collection. The adoption of the same concession regime for crewmembers as for passengers, but with a general concession amount of $450. This would replace the current regime of concessions for crew which includes access to standard passenger concessions once per year, an allowance for alcohol and tobacco every 10 days and the waiver of duty and tax liability under $50 on any other occasion of entry. (2) Estimates of the cost of this measure on the Commonwealth can be found in AppendixA of the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook 2003-04. The costing was determined by using ABS data on arrivals and departures and estimating the impact of passengers bringing in extra goods. (3) No. The proposed measures are waiting on the agreement from the States and Territories. (4) No. Environment: Migratory Birds (Question No. 2806) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 1 December 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2545 (Hansard, 24 November 2003, page 22602), can he confirm whether the interim goals of the threat abatement plan were met over the last five years; if not, why not. (2) Will he be reviewing the status of threatened seabirds following the outcomes of the World Conservation Union (IUCN) Red List review published last week. (1) The interim goal of reducing seabird bycatch to less than 0.05 birds per 1000 hooks has been achieved in most Australian longline fisheries, in particular the Antarctic and Gillnet Hook and Trap fisheries. Although bycatch of albatrosses has been substantially reduced elsewhere, the interim target has not been achieved for the Eastern Tuna and Billfish Fishery because the current mitigation measures are insufficient to manage the bycatch of flesh-footed shearwaters. This problem was not identified at the time the Threat Abatement Plan was prepared in 1998 and will be addressed in the revised plan currently being prepared. (2) No. Trade: Endangered Species (Question No. 2807) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 1 December 2003: What he is doing to determine whether or not the (a) Patagonian Toothfish, (b) Great White Shark, (c) Orange Roughy, (d) Southern Bluefin Tuna, (e) Hound Shark, (f) Blue Shark, (g) Nautilus and Allonautilus species, (h) Spiny Dogfish, (i) Maori Wrasse, and (j) Yellow-Crested Cockatoo will be listed under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Flora and Fauna (CITES). The Australian Government has yet to finalise its approach to the 13th Conference of the Parties of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species scheduled to be held in October 2004. I will

I will make public the Government’s strategy when a decision has been made. Environment: Thermal Paper (Question No. 2808) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 1 December 2003: Has he considered the issue of the use of thermal paper and its toxicity; if so, what conclusions has he reached regarding the future use and disposal of thermal paper; if not, what will he do concerning the future use and disposal of thermal paper. The Environment Protection and Heritage Council, a Council of Australian Environment Ministers which I chair, convenes a waste management working group that determines, investigates and resolves nationally significant waste issues. As the use and disposal of thermal paper and its toxicity has not been raised by states, territories or the paper industry as a nationally significant problem, no action is being considered at this time. I understand thermal paper is only used in small quantities in Australia, and as less than 1% appears in the waste paper stream, it can be incorporated successfully into mixed paper recycling processes. I am advised the barriers to recycling thermal paper are the coatings and chemicals in the paper and its low critical strength. The pulping process uses heat which reacts with the chemicals in the thermal paper, making the waste paper pulp dark in colour. Mills manufacturing ‘white’ office and stationary papers with recycled content are therefore unable to use the thermal paper. Mills producing brown cardboard grades for packaging from recycled paper do not have the same colour specification, but require high critical strength. This process, however, can tolerate small amounts of the low strength thermal paper mixed in with higher strength waste paper grades. Defence Property: Environmental Land Value (Question No. 2809) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 1 December 2003: (1) Is he aware of the possible transfer of land from Defence to the Canberra International Airport on the northern boundary of the airport. (2) What studies has the Government made of the environmental value of this land. (3) Are there any threatened, vulnerable or endangered species located on this section of land. (4) Does the Government intend to dispose of the property adjacent to Canberra International Airport, if so, what action is it taking to ensure that the environmental qualities of this property are safeguarded. (1) Yes. (2) No specific studies have been undertaken to date. Within the Majura Training Area, the Department of Defence has conducted studies on the condition of natural temperate grassland and listed species on the site. (3) There are listed species that are known to occur in the area to the north of Canberra Airport. (4) At this stage the Government has not made a decision on whether to dispose of this land.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Insurance: Medical Indemnity (Question No. 2811) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 1 December 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2340 (Hansard, 24 November 2003, page 22578), (a) what other financial options has the Government considered in meeting the estimated $460 million incurred but not reported (IBNR) liabilities of United Medical Protection Ltd (UMP), and (b) what is the policy rationale for requiring medical practitioners to be subjected to this ‘double jeopardy’ levy. (2) What actuarial advice was relied upon by him and his Department prior to the collapse of UMP and its associated companies that resulted in the calculation of premiums for the IBNR liabilities and will he make this advice public; if not, why not. Will he establish a parliamentary enquiry into how the regulatory scheme for medical indemnity insurance could have allowed IBNR liabilities to accrue without adequate safeguards to cover such claims; if not, why not. (1) The Government announced on 17 December 2003 the replacement of the IBNR levy with UMP support arrangements. The Government will now be funding some $353 million out of the total estimated UMP IBNR liability of $483 million. (2) The Government did not receive actuarial advice prior to the collapse of UMP. Under the Medical Indemnity Act 2002, UMP was required to provide the Australian Government Actuary (AGA) with an estimate of its unfunded IBNR liabilities. On 30 May 2003 the AGA produced a report detailing UMP’s financial position based on this estimate and determining that UMP’s IBNR liabilities were $460 million as at 30 June 2002. The original IBNR contributions were set based on this advice. The report of the Medical Indemnity Policy Review of 10 December 2003 notes that the AGA estimates the aggregate IBNR for UMP at $483 million as at 30 June 2003. However, any contribution on the part of doctors’ only needs to fund that portion of the IBNR liabilities not already funded through other Government measures, including the High Cost Claims Scheme, subsidies and exemptions. It is estimated that doctors will fund $130 million of the $483 million. Following the recommendations of the report of the Medical Indemnity Policy Review the calculation of the IBNR liabilities and levy will be made more transparent. No. At the time UMP’s IBNR liabilities accrued UMP was not offering contracts of insurance and hence was not subject to Australian Government prudential supervision. Subsequently insurers have been brought under the supervision of the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority. Government Departments: Legal Services (Question No. 2813) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 1 December 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2480 (Hansard, 24 November 2003, page 22593), how effective is this policy in preventing departments and agencies retaining such legal practitioners. (2) What legally binding effect and standing does this policy have at law. (3) Can any person challenge at law an appointment of a barrister or solicitor, or other legal practitioner, by a Commonwealth Government agency where that legal practitioner has been previously declared bankrupt; if so, who; if no person can challenge the appointment, what action
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:will she take to ensure that the law is changed such that those appointments may be challenged; if no action will be taken, why not. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) The previous answers provided to the honourable member on this issue indicates that neither the Department of Veterans’ Affairs, the Repatriation Commission nor any other agency within my portfolio responsibilities, have engaged any of the named Barristers or legal practitioners who have taken refuge in insolvency as a means of avoiding tax. I believe that the policy is effective in my portfolio. (2) The responsibility for providing any such legal advice concerning the status of the policy issued by the then Attorney-General on this issue is a matter on which the honourable member will need to approach the Attorney-General. (3) Any changes to entrench this policy in law would appear to be a matter for the consideration of the Attorney-General having regard to the powers contained in section 55ZF of the Judiciary Act 1903. President of the United States (Question No. 2823) Ms Hoare asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 December 2003: (1) Is he aware of reports of the United States of America’s demands of the Government of the United Kingdom in relation to security measures for the visit of the President of the United States to that country, in particular, (a) the request for diplomatic immunity to armed American special agents, and (b) the request to allow American special agents to carry so-called mini-guns. (2) Were similar requests made by the Government of the United States of the Australian Government for the recent visit of the President of the United States to Australia; if so, did the Australian Government refuse the United States Government request and, if it did not refuse the request, why not. The requests made by the United States to the government of the United Kingdom relating to the security measures for the visit of the President of the United States are a matter between those two governments. I am therefore unable to comment on whether diplomatic immunity for armed American special agents was requested, or whether a request was made to allow American special agents to carry so called mini-guns in the United Kingdom. However, I can confirm no requests for diplomatic immunity for US security officers or to carry so called mini-guns were made to the Australian Government in the planning for or during the visit of the President of the United States to Australia. Australian Grand Prix: Tobacco Advertising Exemption (Question No. 2825) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 1 December 2003: (1) Will he provide a copy of the report by the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research which he considered when deciding that the Australian Grand Prix was an event of international significance; if not, why not. (2) In respect of granting exemptions from tobacco advertising restrictions for major events, can he confirm that he stated "Economic hardship is not a factor… the Minister must be satisfied that the event is of international significance, and that a failure to specify the event would be likely to result in the event not being held in Australia.”
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) Can he clarify whether he does not have to or must not consider whether having an event in Australia is good for the economy and can he explain why this anomaly was included in the regulatory framework. (4) Can he confirm that he is granting yet another exemption from tobacco advertising restrictions for the next Australian Grand Prix. (5) Does he and the Government still have a commitment, as expressed by the former Minister for Health, that tobacco advertising exemptions will be phased out by 2006. (1) A copy of the report by the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research was not included in the Australian Grand Prix Corporation’s application for an exemption for the 2004 Australian Grand Prix. The Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 (the Act) does not require it to be provided. (2) Yes, I can confirm this statement which quotes section 18 of the Act. (3) In order to grant an exemption under section 18 of the Act, the Minister must be satisfied that the event is of international significance and that Australia would be likely to lose the event if an exemption were not granted. When determining these matters, the Minister must also have regard to the Guidelines made under section 18, which do not refer to economic matters. (4) I can confirm that the 2004 Australian Grand Prix has been granted an exemption under section 18 of the Act. A notice specifying the event under subsection 18(2) was published in the Commonwealth of Australia Special Gazette of 1 August 2003. (5) The Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Amendment Act 2000 removes the discretion of the Minister for Health and Ageing to grant an exemption under section 18 of the Act from 1 October 2006. Australian Flag: Logos (Question No. 2838) Mr Organ asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 3 December 2003: (1) Is he aware that the Australian flag sold by BigW as part of the International Rugby Board (IRB) World Cup Official Merchandise was an Australian Flag with IRB logos attached down the side where the Union Jack is placed. (2) Is he able to say whether the IRB obtained official permission to use the national flag in this way and whether the action constitutes defacing the national flag. (1) and (2) I am advised that approval was given by my Department to the use of the Australian National Flag in conjunction with the IRB logo as the use of the logo to embellish the headband of the flag does not constitute defacement of the flag. Trade: Philippine Bananas and Pineapples (Question No. 2873) Mr Katter asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 4 December 2003: (1) Is he aware that notwithstanding scientific findings by Biosecurity Australia in its Draft Impact Risk Analysis of July 2002 that the Philippines has 22 pests and diseases that Australia does not have, the Australian Ambassador to the Philippines was reported to have said that Australia “is willing to accept Philippine bananas and pineapples but under certain conditions”.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Howard
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) Is he aware of reports that risk management involved with a grant of access for Filippino bananas would necessitate some 20 tonnes of the toxic, ozone-depleting chemical, methyl bromide, being sprayed onto the imported fruit to decontaminate it. (3) Is he also aware that there are no measures that will efficiently control the disease Moko. (4) Is Biosecurity Australia, a Commonwealth Agency, subject to the provision of the Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 which states that “The Commonwealth or a Commonwealth agency must not take inside or outside the Australian jurisdiction an action that has, will have or is likely to have a significant impact on the environment inside or outside the Australian jurisdiction.”; if so, does Biosecurity Australia hold the required approval, declaration or other permit to allow it to give access to Filippino bananas and on what basis was such an approval given. (5) Will exposing Australian flora and fauna to 22 diseases and pests and/or to the heavy amounts of toxic chemicals used for risk management be likely to have a significant effect on the environment; if so, should the “precautionary principal” in the Act be applied in this case. (6) Does he intend to permit Biosecurity Australia to proceed with the decision to admit bananas from the Philippines. (1) No. (2) No. (3) No. (4) Yes, Biosecurity Australia is subject to section 28 of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). Biosecurity Australia does not require an EPBC Act approval, declaration or permit. An importer would require a permit, issued by the Director of Quarantine under the Quarantine Act 1908. A decision by the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth agency to grant an authorisation under the Quarantine Act 1908 is not an action that requires approval under the EPBC Act (section 524). (5) The potential direct and indirect impacts of quarantine pests and pathogens on the environment are considered by Biosecurity Australia, in consultation with the Department of the Environment and Heritage, as an integral part of each import risk analysis. They may be considered significant subject to the individual assessment and risks associated with a proposed import. Methyl bromide is commonly used around the world as a quarantine fumigant. Its use for quarantine purposes is presently exempt from the phase-out provisions of the Montreal Protocol. The Government has provided funding of $816,000, through the Ozone Protection Reserve, to support methyl bromide phase-out projects. This includes $72,000 to trial alternatives for quarantine and pre-shipment uses. (6) See (4) above. Employment: Job Seekers (Question No. 2882) Mr Albanese asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 4 December 2003: Over the duration of ESC2 and for each employment assistance program, what were the levels of educational attainment (i.e. did not complete Year 12; completed secondary school; holds a university qualification; or holds a trade qualification) of those jobseekers who secured employment after participating in an employment assistance program.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Along with an extensive range of other performance data, details of the educational attainment of the job seekers for whom employment outcomes are achieved is routinely made publicly available in the quarterly Labour Market Assistance Outcomes report (LMAO) published by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations on Australian Workplace internet site (www.workplace.gov.au). Copies of the LMAO for the three financial years of the second Employment Service Contract period are provided and copies are available from the House of Representatives table office.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice
